I'm for Prairie Dog day. This would bring attention to the fact that the Black Footed Prairie Dog is being poisoned by the tens of thousands by ranchers.

And the maker of the poison? None other than Monsanto, which seems determined to wreck havoc on our environment one way or another. The poison is particularly painful to these little creatures because it causes them to bleed internally for several days until they die. When they are hunted by hawks, owls, coyotes and other natural predators, Monsanto's poison spreads throughout the ecology.

So give Chuck a break and send a message to Monsanto--stop poisoning our environment.

"An elegant public appearance".
Yay, another excuse for a Hello Dolly tune!

Tune of "Elegance"

Hey New York
Appearing here
Showing if spring is nearing here
While we watch her suave demeanor
We note her nails could not be cleaner

So will she be high fiving soon
Telling if spring is arriving soon
See how elegant
Chuck is smooth and elegant
As she says if the long winter is off.

On TV
Behold at last
Forecast will soon be told at last
From the class we call rodentia
(though the mayor is in absentia)

Are we in for luck, we blog
Soon we'll learn that from Ms Chuck G Hogg
And she's elegant
Every move is elegant
And we all hope a long winter is off!

Whistle pig? That's a new one--you truly do learn something new every day.

Up where I live they are referred to as woodchucks. There are two living in a hole on my property, and my goodness, they are heavy little devils. If you don't mind a few holes, they are welcome guests. It is enjoyable to see them come out, lift and wrinkle their noses, and enjoy the sunshine during summer months.
I adore that feeling of being tiny in the overwhelming power of the water. Communion indeed.

The transcendence described by the author in this naive and silly essay will disappear in an instant when even strong swimmers get into trouble at a dangerous place like Palihole. Readers beware. The power of the ocean here is enormous and can kill you. In fact, it often does. Get your sublime moments just watching the pounding surf, and even then be careful, as people are swept away by rogue waves all the time. The NYT should add a warning to this article.
Great story....makes me want to head back there !

It is the exposure of our children to Nature's wonders, every day we can, that should guide every parent.  Snorkeling on the Big Island, Greece, Australia has opened my family's eyes to the underwater wonders of the oceans.  Surfing and fishing throughout has garnered respect for the sustenance the oceans provide.  Living it and showing them every day will protect nature for their generation and they will be prepared to sustain it for their children.
There is great healing when we enter the waters. We lose something of ourselves as we gain peace.

I live on Kauai and year after year, read about accidental drownings from people like Tsui who are eschew safety and knowledge of our dangerous currents for some transcendental experience. To date, one month into 2017, three tourists have died in Kauai waters.

Don't think Mother Nature will protect you, she won't. Don't be lulled into a false sense of security by the beauty all around. We locals take extreme care but often have to pay the price for heedless tourists like Tsui who get into trouble. A small island, with 70,000 permanent residents our small county budget is strained with all the rescues of blithe people like Tsui from our waters and mountain trails. She's lucky she didn't get swept out to Niihau swimming in Polihale. I'm glad she made it back okay, but this article is a serious disservice to other visitors.

Didn't Tsui see the ocean safety videos all over the baggage claim area when she landed here? Apparently not. THAT would have been a better story.

1. yeah, if you are white/howli, i would not recommend trying to "swim with the locals" unless you want to get beaten up.
2. what is funny in hawaii is that everywhere they warn about rip tides so you wont get drowned, but no one mentions that if you are used to body surfing elsewhere, that the waves are about 3x as powerful. first day out in kawaii, caught a great shore break just as i would in the continental usa. but it slammed me so hard like a Mack truck into the sand I suffered a torn labrum.....be careful even with swimming. you gotta know where you are.

To swim
to breathe
with elemental ease

To bathe
in sea
in solitary peace

Wash away fear
cast away tears
in the bathysphere
of Poseidon's reign

A fluid self
immersed in the world
nothing more
need be gained

So much of the close to shore coral has died this past year on Maui. Our polititions don't care. Sediment from building sites, continual EPA fines paid for sewage treatment injection well violations, instead of fixing the problem. Almost no enforcement of the already minimal regulations. The beautiful Parrot fish that cleans coral, rotting in Phillipino Fish stores for $10.

Not the white, bleached coral that we read about as the result of Global Warming, which maybe can come back, but brown, dead, covered coral.

In a film about a 1960s-70s Kaua'i north shore hippie villlage called "Taylor Camp", Suzanne "Bobo" Bollin, a long time resident, describes how she gets ready to swim from Haena to Polihale in big waves and with big sea animals. Her process, born of years of experience, is fascinating.
Take a look at the film after reading this article and you will have a deeper understanding of watermen and waterwomen and their relationship with the ocean.
Thank you, John Wehrheim, Robert Stone and Tom Vendetti for making this film and allowing this former Taylor Camper to relive the happiest days of so many lives.

Thanks for the memories!  I lived at the foot of Diamond Head for 8 years, renting the upstairs in an old Hawaiian house that belonged to a beautiful lady who had been Miss Hawaii in 1958.  It was across the street from a small beach park.  My daily ritual was to roll out of bed, slip into a bikini, swim out to the reef and back, shower and go to work.  In the evenings I would repeat the process but would stash a martini on the rocks to enjoy afterwards as I watched the sunset.  It was a heavenly time.  How I miss the daily sensation of being embraced by those waters.

Thank you for the lovely article. After graduating from college, I spent 3 months traipsing throughout Kauai: surfing, swimming, and getting in above my head. On Christmas Day, 1999, I nearly drowned off of the Na Pali Coast. The experience humbled me. I have a more cautious, but still close relationship with the ocean ever since. What a magical place.

You didn't mention it, but the 11 mile Kalalau Trail on Kauai will also change your life. If you are not careful or simply unlucky, it will take it as well. During my hike I was trailed by a family who was retracing the steps of their son who disappeared there, never to be found, presumably swept away in a flash flood.

I had a much different and yet still meaningful experience at Tunnels Beach last January.  During the winter months weather conditions change and turn Tunnels into a maelstrom of 10 to 20 foot waves breaking all over the place in different directions and in constantly changing patterns.  While my family hiked, I sat on the beach and watched this event for hours.  There was something happening that couldn't be explained but could only be felt.  There was quite a group of us just sitting and staring.  The power and magnificence of the ocean is mesmerizing.
Thanks so much for writing this - so many of my own thoughts seem to be in your writing.
The German language provides the word "Waldeinsamkeit" for hikers in the forest.  Is there a similar word for swimmers in the ocean?  This article justifies such a word.

Many Hawaiians believe that those who take pleasure in the ocean's beauty have a responsibility to malama "take care of" the ocean in return. I'm afraid that if this message is lost that Hawaii's beaches will be too. Waikiki is projected to be underwater by 2100 due to rising sea levels. Also, remember to always use mineral-based sunscreen instead of chemical-based sunscreens. Just one drop of chemical-based sunscreen (the majority of sunscreens) is enough to kill coral within the volume of six olympic-sized swimming pools. Aloha!

Impressed you even waded in at Polihale, but your descriptions of both that beach and Tunnels are spot on.

This article perfectly encapsulates why I feel Hawaii pulling me back to visit year after year...
Wonderful essay. Thank you.
Heaven

My wife and I moved from Long Island to the north shore of Kauai (Rented a house on Tunnels beach for $3,000/month) in 1998.  Lived there for 3 years, then returned to NY to be near my kids.  My kids visited us for a few days and that was great. Then they did the other islands. That experience was the best of my life.  Kauai was paradise.  I hope it till is now.

Ocean people just can't  get enough of the ocean, and we in Hawaii are lucky enough to be there every day.  There are mountain people too, and I'm glad they stay elsewhere  because we ocean people are happy as is.

I grew up learning to swim in the colder waters of Massachusetts Bay, but have lived here on Oahu for many years.  Swimming in Hawaii is quite different, but just as wonderful as the writer describes.  Nevertheless, it is worth noting that a surprisingly high percentage of the local population cannot swim--“'almost amphibious' from birth" is no longer the norm.  My own two children took swimming lessons, but many do not.
Oh, how I miss swimming at Ala Moana Beach Park. I can imagine myself swimming back from the far 'course' marker sighting off the Ilikai.

Our daughter moved to Sydney,Australia 5 years ago.We have visited there 3 times and have fallen in love with the Australian swim culture. We always stay in Bondi. Starting at dawn there is a parade of surfers and swimmers getting into the ocean before their work day. On the weekends the children are taking ocean survival lessons. 6 and 7 year olds learning how to rescue and navigate the rough surf. The ease and grace in which they swim thru the ocean is truly something to behold. Thanks for the great article.

Thank you for reminding me of those sun drenched days long ago; bodysurfing at Brenneke's and swimming laps in Waiohai lagoon. My favorite memory is of jumping off the boat a mile off the shore into the deep blue almost purple water; a purely spontaneous action without hesitation to the ocean's beckoning to come in! Lovely beautiful Kauai!

Reminds me, somewhat, of my summer days spent at Cape May, N.J. while growing up in Philadelphia. Going to the beach was a joy I feel today as I recall wave surfing and floating on the waves in a rented air filled surfer. How I miss those days and the feeling of being at one with the ocean and nature. Nothing can take that away. Maybe being born under the sign of Aquarius has something to do with it!
Thanks for offering this article to all who love the ocean.

The puzzle was great fun. My quibble isn't even a quibble, as the thing I'm about to address isn't incorrect. But crosswords in papers such as NYT are sometimes instructional. At this time, in the US, there is a shocking lack of knowledge (and a concomitant spread of disinformation) about people who live in ADEN and places of its ilk. The clue for 20A mentions Hebrew. That's fine; I studied Hebrew and I know how it's written.

But Arabic is also written RIGHTTOLEFT; it's spoken by 400 million people; and it's one of the 6 official languages of The United Nations. I wouldn't have blanched if 20A had been clued for Arabic.

Any other astronomy geeks out there waiting for Deneb to appear in tonight's puzzle?

Altair - Vega - Deneb are the three bright stars that make up the "Summer Triangle" - three important locator stars for the night sky during the summer months in the northern hemisphere. Having Altair (the Eagle's Eye) in yesterday's puzzle and Vega (the Eagle's Fall) in today's is really teasing for skywatchers if we don't see Deneb (the Swan's Tail) tonight!

I found this to be a very clever debut. I think what made it a bit tricky is that many of the answers had letters that would be in the same box whether the word went forward or backward. The point has already been adequately covered, but – as a regular reader of Hebrew books from FRONT TO BACK, I feel obliged to describe my own solving experience.

My first entry in this puzzle was 20A RIGHT TO LEFT, matching 50A: LEFT TO RIGHT, which I entered soon thereafter. The theme was clear enough and I managed to fill in most of the grid. However, even after I ran into the incompatibilities in the NW corner, the idea that I have been reading my books from BACK TO FRONT did not enter my mind until I invoked “check” on square 20 and found B. I completed the solve with a few more perfunctory “check”s and “reveals”, but the fun was gone.

Very nice to be the puzzle's centerpiece!

The puzzle didn't need the bracketed reactions. It wold have worked fine without them. A couple of the non-backward answers could have been backward answers (STEP, STEM). The puzzle has a STEP up, but not a STIR up.

Overall, I, who am often directionally challenged, enjoyed being directionally challenged. Nice one!

This helps to make up for yesterday and not getting the theme at all. The hints certainly helped. I had thought of left to right first and was unsure about how to enter it, but was virtually positive of NATO, and then thought of BACK TO FRONT (from an English language point of view). A few downs later I noticed ESUF at24A, so all that was left to figure out was the pattern of backward entries. That was confirmed with the next theme entry.

I found it easier that a lot of Thursdays, but it was very clever and great fun to solve, so many congratulations to our latest debut constructor, and looking forward to more from Alex.

Very clever! I enjoyed the challenge! We won't see these every day. Kudos for the ingenuity in crafting it. I always enjoy the mind game of figuring out alternate meanings of the clues. A line cutter...

The best puzzles result in us filling in all too common words and phrases, but with clues that are only a challenge because of their various possible meanings. With these ideal puzzles, we struggle to get a foothold, then advance quadrant by quadrant, only to look back at our final result and shake our head bemused and wonder aloud "well now that I see the true meaning of the clue, it looks easy!.

As a high school teacher of Advanced Placement (AP) Art History, I am forever telling my students that Leonardo's name is 'Leonardo' and not 'da Vinci'. Born illegitimate, Leonardo did not have a surname, and 'da Vinci' is a way of distinguishing him from others named Leonardo, meaning 'the one from (da) Vinci.' While da Vinci may be a regrettably popular name, it is only rather recently popular, partly because of the Dan Brown book The Da Vinci Code. Art historically (and historically) speaking, it is incorrect to call this artist da Vinci, and scholars rarely do. All of my former students delight in telling me about all of the times they find, read, or hear the artist being referred to as da Vinci. I realize I'm just being picky . . .

I'm bothered by the answer to the Hebrew clue. I wanted RIGHT TO LEFT (though I did consider writing it in backwards). It seems to English readers that you start at the back of a Hebrew book, but in a Hebrew book, that's no more the back than it is on an English book.

When you lay a Hebrew book down with the front cover facing up, the spine is to the right. An English book's spine would be to the left. But for both books, that's the front, and page 1 is what you find once you open the front cover. You don't open the front cover of a Hebrew book and find הסוף (the end), which would be the case if you had to read the book BACK TO FRONT.

Does this make sense?
Congratulations on the debut!  You had me coming and going.

Unlike yesterday, I saw the theme of this one pretty early, over in the GERI-RENEE-TSAR area. That didn't make entering letters backwards any easier, though! I did ponder whether 20A would be RIGHT TO LEFT (meaning pages) or BACK TO FRONT (meaning the whole thing). Still, it was fun. Welcome, Mr. Eaton-Salners!

What is carefully left out of arguments for the wall is you do not make money from a wall (beyond the initial construction). You make money by controlling passage through the wall. Donald Trump knows this. The purpose of the wall is not to eliminate drugs but to facilitate the extraction/extortion of "rents" from smugglers. Smugglers with easy access to the United States have no incentive for payments to politicians, lobbyists, promoters and P.R. people or others to facilitate access to the US narcotics market. High-value, high-volume drug shipments are not carried across the border by large numbers of immigrants.....they are too vulnerable and too difficult to control. Valuable shipments pass through secreted in the thousands of cargo trucks that enter from Mexico daily. If those shipments can be corralled into a limited number of passageways the chance to divert cartel profits from the Mexican side of the border to the US increases. That is what the wall is about, not a bunch of farmworkers and dishwashers. The access fees now paid as dark money campaign contributions (note how quickly President Trump filled for re-election so he could keep incoming contributions), manipulated real estate deals, and other transactions can rise if gatekeeping is more effective. Stop thinking about the wall as a passive defense. It is to skim profits from the drug trade so the heroin and meth sold in Indiana benefits American border-watchers, not the Mexican pipeline. Just business.

If we’re no longer talking seriously about WHETHER the wall will be built, then I’m perfectly happy to focus on who will be paying for it. But Mr. Grillo and millions of others should note the epochally successful distraction that Trump has engineered in this matter: he’s split the championship of open-borders and resistance to the wall itself between those who resist it for its pivot on illegal immigration policy and those who are outraged that Mexico is called on to pay for it.

Best-guesses at present are that the wall will cost $20 billion, not $12-$15 billion. And if we had to pay for every dime of it, I would regard the money well-spent to regain control of our borders. And if part of that $20 billion were spent to more effectively interdict the caravans of illicit drugs that the Mexican and other cartels employ, then even better and MORE worth the money.

Problem is that if the U.S. markets for illicit drugs become largely inaccessible, what are those cartels likely to do in the societies below our southern border to prosper? Likely nothing Mexico wants to seriously consider.

Just ignore Trump’s distraction about who will be paying for the wall. Consider instead what it is about Latin American societies that allow the rise and dominance of lawless, murderous cartels, and what you can effectively do about them.

Friendships or alliances among nations aren't personal, of course, but maintaining them requires some of the same skills: seeing the other party's point of view, respect, an aura of receptivity, reserving judgment until a full understanding has been reached.

We've all had family members who take every perceived slight as the first shot in a war. Those are the ones we aren't really friends with; those are the ones we dread seeing at the holiday table. I feel as if to our allies, the U.S. has now become that obnoxious relative.

Apples and Oranges:
Buried deep in an appendix to the Pew study widely touted by the anti-wall, anti-serious-border-control crowd that supposedly shows a (minuscule) "net negative" immigration from Mexico (during one or two measly recent years):
Apples (numbers taken for inward flow into the US from Mexico):
U.S. Government numbers for persons born in Mexico living in the USA.
Oranges (numbers taken for outward flow from the USA into Mexico):
Mexican Government numbers combining not only persons born in Mexico returning to Mexico to live there but also persons born anywhere outside Mexico coming into Mexico.
Not only different sources, but also fundamentally different methodology:
Clearly, the Mexican government numbers (taken as the flow out from the US)
include children born in the US to parents born in Mexico,
not only giving the lie to the claim of "net negative" immigration
but also giving the lie to the mantra that America's "cruel" immigration "system" necessarily "tears families apart".

There are two parties to a border wall. Party wall agreements are common in real estate here, there and elsewhere. Trump is intimate with the concept. We either want a border wall or we don't. The voters have spoken and Trump is going to implement.

So, we force Mexico to pay, de facto payments levied from import taxes makes most sense. Prices of Mexican imports rise and US producers become more competitive and employ more people, it's a matter of balance.

Even a marginal 3% tax on Mexican imports would pay for the wall over ten years. So we pay $2.16/lb rather than $2.10/lb for some Mexican tomatoes. I doubt that will cause a problem for too many here.

Mitch McConnell has said this Supreme Court nominee -- even before the nomination -- will be confirmed, and there should be no doubt Republicans can make it happen. The country is in this box because of a distinction that Harry Reid failed to make in changing the filibuster rule. Executive branch nominees should be confirmed with a simple majority: they are nominees of an elected, term-limited official and serve at the pleasure of the president and thus are effectively term-limited.

Confirming judicial nominees to life-tenured positions by a simple majority is unwise. It can create or further the appearance that the judiciary is a partisan branch, thus undermining confidence that the courts deliver justice. It encourages the legislature to default on its responsibilities and to allow the judicial branch to function as a supreme legislature.

Democrats should propose both a law and a constitutional amendment that would advance the country's interest in having higher public confidence in the judiciary:

All nominees for Article III judges must be voted upon by the Senate within 120 days of the nomination and the votes of 55% of senators are required for confirmation. This would end the ongoing problem of 10%-15% vacancies in the federal judiciary and codify the dictum that great changes should not be decided by narrow majorities.

What is the meaning of the concept of a Constitutional "originalist"?  How far back do we go to determine "original intent"?  The original Constitution did not include the Bill of Rights, which were the first 10 amendments. The original Constitution granted full citizenship only to white male property owners. The 19th Amendment, granting the right to vote to women, was not ratified until 1920.  Are these so-called originalists advocating that we return to the 18th century?

I am not a legal scholar, I did not study constitutional law, I did not study philosophy at Oxford like Cruz or Gorsuch. I do however know that if I wish to know original intent I must have a late 18th century dictionary to understand what the words meant.
In the late 18th century there was only ONE dictionary and everybody who had a library and read and wrote used that dictionary.
Samuel Johnson's dictionary was the authoritative dictionary of the English language and in 1776 and 1783 you wanted to read or write English you knew Dr Samuel Johnson.
In 1783 Militias were the trainbands of a nation they were professional military and asserted the nations right to exist. Arms were weapons of war. Neither word Militia nor Arms had a secondary meaning. The second Amendment has nothing to say about citizens and their rights to have guns. I think it's worth noting that under an "Originalist" interpretation of the constitution and a "Textualist" interpretation of statutes, which purport to follow the intent of the Framers, the outcomes always coincides with the political & policy agendas of the modern Republican Party. It's a miracle how prescient the Framers were.

"...an originalist, a judicial breed that cynics define as people who believe that if the founding fathers were around today, they would be best friends and agree on everything."

A cynic--like Diogenes--believes people are not as virtuous as they seem--certainly not as they say; absolutely certain for politicians..

A true cynic believes this about him/herself as well.

The founding fathers were themselves cynics--they did their best to design a form of government as foolproof as possible. You know why. It's hardly majority rule; it's much more due process, checks and balances.

But nothing's perfect. Fools sneak in-- spinning their mandate as raw majority rule--to override due processes.

"Originalism" makes the constitution a bible--eternal truth, known infallibly. As though 21st century reality was the same as 18th. As though word-meanings don't evolve.

As though only one interpretation of those words is possible--thereby transforming religious fundamentalism into legal fundamentalism.

But religious fundamentalism is itself a joke. Who believes "let he who eats sour grapes have is own teeth set on edge" is about grapes?

Jeremiah's words--a statement of individual vs vicious vicarious liability --punishing future generations for ancestral sins--a rejection of Mosaic law.

The Constitution too is not only subject to amendment, but creative interpretation--adaptation for an evolving world. As a bible it's a joke too; just as the Bible is.

Extreme measures should be used only for the very abnormal and anti-democratic measures taken by this president. And there are going to be many of those.

It is important to separate the normal political actions of a partisan president from the abnormal actions of an autocrat. These latter actions threaten the future of the country and should be resisted by patriots on both sides of the political spectrum. On the principle that two wrongs don’t make a right, it’s not enough to say “they” broke with established practice by refusing to consider Judge Garland’s nomination, so “we” can break with practice by filibustering Judge Gorsuch’s nomination.  A better argument begins with the Republican’s reason for refusing to consider Garland: the nominee of a lame duck president would not reflect public will.  So public will: a solid majority of voters in the presidential election voted for Clinton, and majorities support gun control, abortion rights, campaign finance reform, and public policy addressing climate change.  Given these facts, opponents of Gorsuch have a strong case that Trump owed the public at least a moderate pick, a unifying gesture that people across the political spectrum could agree is beyond Trump’s personal and political sensibilities.  This argument might resonate with enough moderate, by temperament at least,  Republican Senators—whose opinions regarding the issues listed above reflect the public will—to avert a change to Senate rules, allow a successful filibuster of Gorsuch, and force Trump to make a more moderate choice.  However slight the likelihood of this outcome . . .

Originalism has no historic basis and those who advocate it are unconscionably ignorant and/or hypocritical. The Founderd were not a bunch of amiable buddies. For example, Hamilton and Madison had an notoriously antagonistic relationship. They endured a long and fractious Constitutional Convention and were willing to compromise because the only thing they agreed on was the necessity to replace the Articles of Confederation with a stronger and clearer articulation of the powers of government.

The Supreme Court under Chief Justice John Marshall formed the basis for the exercise of judicial review under Article III of the Constitution in the 1803 Marbury v Madison decision. (Google it if you don't know about it.) Originalist views on amendments are very confusing, since the Founder were only involved in the first ten. Interpretations of Bill of Rights are especially peculiar in the context of today's technology. The Founders could not have envisioned how the 1st Amendment would protect speech and the press in the context of today's media or that the 2nd amendment would apply to ownership of assault weapons by individuals. Originalists also ignore precedent when it is inconvenient to their personal or political views. Scalia and Thomas are prime examples.

Chief Justice Warren was appointed by Eisenhower and Justice Kennedy by Reagan, so Gorsuch might have the intelligence and integrity to surprise us, but no one should count on it.

In my view I believe that all of us should support a serious effort to establish term limits for Supreme Court Justices.
Surely a term of service of 10 to 15 years would suffice given any number of considerations.
Well experienced candidates would be chosen and would be able to leave before reaching unreasonable advanced ages...... thus chosen at age 55 to 60 and able to retire at 70 to 75.
Medical problems would be of lesser importance as well.

Political circumstances and effects would be greatly reduced and more attention would be given to the selection of worthwhile candidates with good backgrounds of judicial experience.
Term limits would make the entire process of selection less contentious and would serve to remove the usual rancor associated with the process.

In addition the selection process would move forward more quickly and thus reduce the time that a Supreme Court seat would remain vacant.
The issue would also be of less importance in presidential elections.

We live in a time of rapid change in all venues and the Supreme Court should reflect this obvious fact as well.

Originalism is a phony legal concept.  For example, the Second Amendment clearly states that the "paramount" goal of the unabridged right to bear arms was the need for a "well-regulated militia". There was no army at the time.  Accordingly, since we now have an army, hundreds of years later, the government has every right to restrict the right to bear arms to protect public welfare.  After all, the Founding Fathers didn't duel each other with glocks back then. But the NRA is in charge here, not the government. Reagan's Chief of Staff required every paper going to the President be reduced to a one page summary on top. Reagan studied the top pages.

Jimmy Carter is criticized for doing too much the opposite, getting into such intimate detail on his own that he did not do his own job.

There is something to be said for Reagan's approach. General George C. Marshall ran WW2 that way. He said that any briefer who could not explain himself in five minutes just did not understand what he was talking about. WW2 was run on five minute presentations.

We have not yet heard what rules are in place for materials given to Trump. There may not even be rules yet. However, "study" is not his job description. Things that get to the President's desk have been studied, and they are there for action on well understood, well studied points of decision.

They absolutely should remove the filibuster from the nomination process, whether this involves obstructing Gorsuch or not. It's clear that both parties belive SCOTUS nominations are a legislative process now, not an executive one.

Clearly republicans agree the "advice and consent" clause is more important than the President's right to nominate, and if the Democrats had really believed that Presidential authority superceded the legislative process, Obama could have simply told Judge Garland to start sitting on the bench, without Senate approval, and let the chips fall where they may.

So let's face it - this is a legislative process now. Consider what would happen if the senate majority leader went to the president with a name and said "this is the only person we will consider hearings on." There is nothing a sitting president could do except force the court to be short again.

Since this is now a purely legislative process, it should require a simple majority, not a supermajority. The only difference between a court nomination and a normal legislative vote now is that the President has an un-overridable veto in the form of actually having to name the nominee.

President Bannon is the one in charge and Pence is waiting in the wings to take over after the two rabid dogs (Bannon and Trump) take each other out.  There is no good outcome for the American people in any of these situations.
Perhaps, at the next press conference, someone should ask Trump what Harriet Tubman is famous for!  Would be fun to see how he can't answer.
Going nuclear: will someone in a position to know about Trump's tax situation please purchase a one-way ticket to somewhere, and then spill the beans.

I vote for "B" - Pence's Pomeranian ... just because it also brings to mind "pompadour" and "pompous."
Before doing so, however, we need to make sure that Pomeranians, as well as the other two breeds, are "legitimately" American, and can produce birth certificates (which cannot include the state of Hawaii) to prove it.

I vote to save our ammunition for the next, truly meaningful fight.  Gorsuch, I suspect, may turn into a Souter as his thoughtfulness and friendship with Kennedy along with the vapidity of conservative arguments will likely drive him away from Alito and Thomas and into the arms of the left.
Speaking about White House pets, has anyone noticed the President's new lap dog, Sean Hannity?

In the alliterative allusions, I immediately hopped to one that is not nice, in Yiddish, for Pence's Puppy. Maybe we should refrain from alliteration.

So the question for the Democrats is to figure out if they want send have the GOP go nuclear this early - still two forgettable years away from midterms, or wait and force them to use it later. Tricky question. Letting the "Nuclear Option" just become another tool is going to make it less outrageous each day. People just forgot about McConnell's coup last fall. Regardless, unless he has a huge skeleton to hide, Judge Gorsuch is our next Justice, because the GOP has demonstrated that the rules only matter when someone else has to follow them.

But we will have a Justice that opposes, in a big way, most of the things that Democratic voters support. No one is going to nominate a moderate. This is war, and gloating is encouraged.

So the Dems would be best suited to find a way to make a big, messy, noisy public and purely symbolic protest that nonetheless does not make the "Nuclear Option" a new normal. Frankly, I don't think any of them are manipulative enough. They need their own Bannon for that.

The GOP covered up Reagan's Alzheimer's for three years (William F. Buckley told me, and others, in 1986 that Reagan "has been ga-ga for two years,") so how long will they ignore Trump's obvious mental and emotional instability? Collins is funny, but we are all laughing through our tears. Our nation is in great peril from Trump's instability.
Originalism doesn't even work for the Bible. It's goofy to think it should  work for the Constitution.

Judge Neil Gorsuch will fill the seat left vacant after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia. He holds a strict originalist interpretation of the U.S. Constitution, as the Founding Fathers would have intended it 230 years ago. These are the basic beliefs also held by Justice Scalia. That, in any case, is the theory advanced in pundits’ commentary since the announcement of the Gorsuch nomination. A review of history strongly suggests that in practice Judge Gorsuch should not follow Justice Scalia as his standard.
Since its creation by Article III of the U.S. Constitution, the Supreme Court has handed down decisions that have shaped American history. As “the court of last resort”, the Supreme Court has the final authority to interpret constitutional questions and federal law and to uphold or reverse decisions made by lower courts. Justice Scalia was an inevitable, but unintended, consequence of this authority. A brilliant but shameless sophist, he oftentimes made his case with spurious arguments, ignoring factual evidence to the contrary. Conspicuously, he invented “originalism” to deny others the right to interpret the Constitution while retaining that right for his exclusive and exploitative use.
Pence, Trump, and Gorsuch: prepare for an assault on Thomas Jefferson's great Wall of Separation between Church and State.
I think any breed of small dog will do.  Donald Trump is all, "Focus, focus, focus, SQUIRREL!"

Gorsuch will be known as the illegitimate justice appointed by the illegitimate president. He will sit in the seat stolen from the Democrats and Merrick Garland. If Gorsuch had any honor, he would've decline the appointment.  But of course, power and self will guide his actions.
I see. The opposition party gets help from Russia to win an election, and your response is to have good manners (option B). Sounds like a great plan.

Who is pulling Trump's strings? Pence or Putin?
Gorsuch is an originalist? Has anyone given thought to what that means to women, Blacks, and those unpropertied under 21? The originalists do not necessarily support the 15th, 19th, 25th Amendments. Originalists are the 1% who if they are white men are the only voters. It would be of value to hear Gorsuch's answers to his endorsement of those Amendments, to Hobby Lobby, Citizens United. Does Gorsuch believe that corporations are people? Not a real originalist principle.

Even Mike Pence had to wince. Donald Trump's quote about Frederick Douglass in the PRESENT TENSE, that he was doing an "amazing job" and "I notice", indicated  a level of narcissistic ignorance which can only be described as the ultimate in the surreal, until Kellyanne Conway, Trump's prolix minister of propaganda, blames the improper verb tense on Barack Obama.
I think you overlooked Chinese Crested for breed of dog. The ridiculous top knot is very similar.

Nice work Gail, but here's the thing: Pence or no Pence, Trump's frenetic, deliberate chaos is already reaping dividends. Notice how we have heard little about how Russia, more than likely with Trump in collusion, more or less hacked our election. That should remain an all hands on deck topic, but it's now the can that has been kicked down the road of several news cycles. We should be so lucky if Pence were in charge, but everything has the look of the slick, oily smoke and mirrors Trump has employed his whole life to careen from one self imposed mess to the next. His incompetence and duplicitous intent are what we need to focus on, not a conspiracy theory about who is pulling his strings.

A) Fight! Fight! Fight!

Pence's patsy.

Terrific, Stupendous. Amazing. Great, great. Would somebody please buy Trump a thesaurus? Oh, wait; he doesn't like to read...anything (except "Mein Kampf").

Bannon is running the show.  Pence is just sitting back, hoping that when Bannon convinces the Orange Menace to do something so egregious that even Republicans will have to stand up and take notice.  Pence goes to sleep at night dreaming about article of impeachment and the 25 Amendment, section 4 of the Constitution.

First, I can't stand hearing Trump make comments about "starting WWIII" or "going nuclear." He is the man with the nuclear codes, therefore it is not a casual reference.
Next, I cannot get over the behavior of the Republican party members -- from Trump on down through the Congress: the people who break treaties, change rules of conduct, destroy diplomatic protocols, and generally undo the system of checks and balances that is the basis of our government. Shout out to Paul Ryan, Reince Priebus, Mitch McConnell, Mike Pence, and every other criminal involved. These people have no respect for our democracy, or for principles of a free and diverse society.
And I am stunned that Trump has removed military and intelligence staff from the National Security Council and replaced them with ideological cronies: Steve Bannon.
Another problem: Trump has appointed cabinet members who seem best qualified to dismantle the departments they will head. Betsy DeVos, Rick Perry, Ben Carson et. al. His nominee for Attorney General, Jeff Sessions, is an endorsement of racism.
I too am not interested in trying to guess who has Trump's ear, and I've already figured out that Trump is a snake oil salesman. Perhaps that's why he needs to surround himself with snakes.
I like the word hubris. I think it's coming! The goal is to stay angry, and stay real until it gets here.
Pence has a rabbit, so I am thinking something more Monty Python and the Holy Grail is in order.  Killer Bunny it is, since many without health care will die and Gorsuch is pro death penalty.

The best description of Mike Pence's job is "President in waiting". I could imagine the idea of becoming the President (after his boss is removed by impeachment, resigns impulsively or signs himself in to Bellvue for fatigue), has come to his mind. Only a masochist would stand next to a high rise building as the bricks start to come lose and fall off in an earthquake.

Query: If Trump is really the vice president’s lap dog, do you think we should call him:
A) Pence’s Poodle.
B) Pence’s Pomeranian.
C) Pence’s Pekingese.

My vote goes for Pence's P--sy. (Hint: Trump is being manipulated by Pence and the Alt-Nazis so he's Pence's Patsy.)

The answer to your quiz is A. Trump always brags about negotiating & laid down a marker: he told McConnell that if anyone tries to block his nominee, to do away with the filibuster -- "Go nuclear." (I'm not sure he understands what that means, as he may believe he is enabling Mitch to obliterate Democrats on Capitol Hill literally.) He will do the same if Democrats "save the fight for the next one." Trump will simply tell Mitch to do away with the filibuster every single time he has a nominee, so the idea of "saving" it for the next one is stupid. It should be used to highlight the extreme tactics that Republicans have used. Democrats are a bunch of horrible tacticians. They need to show that they won't bring a water pistol to a tank fight. Force some of the Democrats to decide between their Party and their own electoral survival, if that's what it comes down to. But who really thinks that voters punish politicians for obstruction? That's laughably false, as shown by the Republicans' continued electoral success after 8 years of unprecedented use of the filibuster and obstruction. Supposedly-honorable Sen. Cotton held up the confirmation of several federal judges in July 2015 because they were "not needed." Ted Cruz and Richard Burr are on record for keeping the SCOTUS seat open for four years (8 is fine!) if Hillary had won. Give them a dose of their own medicine. Hold the seat for Garland. Let them see you tear off the steering wheel when you play chicken with extremists.

Drama, deception, deflection.  Thought out, strategized, role-played and successful.  The arrogant and previously overconfident fools - y'know, those political geniuses whose rhetoric and tactics have led to the complete marginalization of their brand - continue to play checkers.  The ascendant opponents are playing GO.  No one sweats losing the checkers game - those arsonist gatherings, the editorial screeds, the resist! silliness.  Enjoy yourselves.  Meanwhile the real game proceeds apace, many steps ahead and fervent in its pursuit of the desired ends.  The hourglass empties.

Trump is a puppet, no doubt.  A puppet generally comes with many strings that must be cooperatively managed to make it dance.  The most apparently string holders: Pence/Evangelicals, Heritage Foundation; Bannon & Flynn; Russia very likely; McConnell/Koch Bros. undoubtedly.  Throw in the body of trump having too little brain, too much brawn, and a delusion that he has received a pre-death canonization...and all the strings are getting tangled very quickly.

You’d like to think your government has its moral vision intact, but with the Trump administration you’ve got another think coming. For example, Mike Pence is prominent among many anti-abortionists in the US who’s self-righteously rigid in claiming an embryo is a helpless life deserving protection.  At the same time, he supports the Muslim ban refusing entry into the US to refugees running for their lives from war and poverty. Why do embryos matter more than refugees?  For one, Pope Francis doesn’t hesitate to insist refugees should be helped and Pence calls himself “an evangelical Catholic.” It’s deceitful to assert abortion is a violation of life and remain so heartless, unworthy of your own religious values and un-American as to ignore men, women and children desperate to survive.

A) Fight! Fight! Fight!
Democrats need to remember and to remind all, especially the President, that they won the popular vote in November. That majority is very likely getting stronger with every new stupidity of the Trump administration.

Gail,
You asked "Query: If Trump is really the vice president’s lap dog, do you think we should call him:

A) Pence’s Poodle.

B) Pence’s Pomeranian.

C) Pence’s Pekingese."

Personally I favor Mike's Mongrel.

I guess the #PresidentBannon meme has gotten DT pretty defensive. He sent Pence off to Judy Woofruff  to be sure to let her know who's boss. "President Trump is "in charge of the Trump administration...But we value Steve Bannon's input..." The "methinks though doth protest too much" sentiment seems to permeate everything these days. Whoever is pulling the strings at this particular moment, it bound not to last. Sir perfectly coiffed is dangerously imbalanced. Complicit republicans have bitten off more than they can gnaw on this time.

I am trying to be reasonable.  A winning candidate has the right to change policies and Trump is no different.  The fact that the changes he wants to make upset all precedent decisions and programs would be acceptable, were these changes the fruit of long reflection and study.  If Trump had been a serious policy maker or attentive student of different proposals, and had come to considered conclusions, aware of their consequences, we could wait for the results.  But we have a person who has none of these characteristics, he is unprepared, unaware and ignorant of the many things he criticizes.  He has already plunged us into disarray, he has alarmed our allies, he has threatened other countries, he has begun the dismantling of environmental protection, taken away support for women's health.  In other words, he presents a real danger to our stability at home and peace abroad.  Republicans think that he can be pushed into fulfilling their restrictive plans, but they are accessories to his deeds and will be responsible for them. They don't know what they are getting into. Meanwhile, they better hold on to his yellow mane.

Gail, what really matters here, what do the Mercers want:

https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/01/no-one-knows-what-t...

So, we say DJT is Mercer's muskrat :)
More like Bannon's bulldog.
Hey, what's that cage strapped on top of Mike Pence's car?

Trump has a deep bench of smart fools, but he is a wind-up toy, turning in circles, changing directions, spewing a reliable hate to "losers" as the horrible consequences of being non-white/foreign/press/for civil rights/a critic/a woman (whose appearance is good or bad by his estimation)/a US ally/experts--Barack. (Love goes to the rich/supremacists/sycophants/the fawning self-absorbed eager for power with inner voids empty of truth/humanity/ethics/justice; bullies and belligerents, friends of Putin.)

His first military ordered action, 10 days in, killed an 8 year old American child, shot through the neck in the middle of the night, and a disputed number of civilians. (Yes, her dead father was a "bad dude" who Barack took out with a drone while he was having lunch.)

Met with "unexpected" heavy small arms fire, in the ensuing fire fight, SEAL Team 6 took one casualty, had four wounded, and withdrew, aborting and apparently failing to complete the mission (capturing a computer system). Some think the bad juju and deception that installed Trump is now coming home to roost.

Sadly, like the SEALs and the smiling child, others will pay the price. Those banned, losing jobs, seeing parents and relatives die, throwing away school, separated from wives and family sent back, forced to renounce their rights despite green cards or naturalized citizens, already know the cost.

The devil--pure evil--diabolical and miniscule, large and veiled in the carnage, is pulling the strings.
When you elect a president who knows only what he knows by watching "the shows," he is anyone's poodle, Putin, Pence, Bannon.

It is a double whammy If the Dems choose to match insanity with insanity

Perhaps the Democratic Party needs to take a good look at itself and weights its options long and short. Copying Republican obstructionism might not be such a good bargain considering the GOP is now ruled by the alt-right gang. Would the Democrat Party be overrun by the alt-left gang?

Besides, considering its weakened state, if the Democrats choose to fight everything, it may end up fighting nothing. Traditionalists would become discouraged, ceding the reign to the anarchists. Violence like those at the UC Berkeley campus last night and during the inauguration in DC last month is still rare but the Dems need to nip it in the bud. They have done enough self-inflicted wounds.

One may disagree and dislike the POTUS but he is right about one thing. The Democratic Party is a mess. Why is Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi still in power? Look, Russian hacking and fake news notwithstanding, the leaked DNC communications have demonstrated how petty some of the operatives were. They did a total disservice to the party and especially to Mrs Clinton. The Dems need to fix their own party first and foremost

One may joke about the VP now but people should study the succession chart. Really, his worldview is not very different from Mr Bannon. Maybe worse if he gains control. If Judge Gorsuch is really about religious liberty, including that of Muslim, maybe one would need his help to defend it

Mike Pence is adorably naïve if he thinks we’re all going to pack a suitcase and obediently move back to the 1950s. The suavity of his pick—sorry, the president’s pick—for the Supreme Court is irrelevant. We’re not going back just because Judge Gorsuch is smart and wears a nice suit.

Some spineless members of the media have suggested that Gorsuch’s amiable, non-confrontational nature will make it easier for him to achieve consensus among his colleagues on the court. They think if he asks nicely and says please and thank you that the justices will consent to a return to back-alley abortions, ignore climate change and consult the bible to see if evolution should be stricken from school curricula.

It seems to me that “originalism” is a red herring. It’s just a way for Gorsuch and his ilk to ignore inconvenient truths that we’ve learned about the world in the last couple of centuries. So when they want to know how to treat women and gay people, they turn to the wisdom of the Bible.

DJT is a ventriloquist’s dummy with so many hands moving his mouth that you’ve got to wonder how it’s anatomically possible. But the president’s profound ignorance on so many subjects is perfect for the puppeteers who want to shove their racist, misogynistic and homophobic agendas down the country’s throat.

So let’s all be originalists about the Gorsuch issue. We’ll treat him the way Mitch McConnell originally treated Merrick Garland. That should make them happy.

If Trump were a truly bold president, he could have nominated Merrick Garland himself. The pundits would have loved it, and the deplorably "centrist" Democrats who can't stand confrontation would have liked it too. People might have said that he was trying to unite the nation. Pure fantasy of course.

I think I like "poodle" best, but Bannon is still more dangerous, if that is possible, than Pence.
Sometimes I wonder if the reason he wants his stupid wall is to keep Americans from escaping.
Mebbe, Trump will do lunch at the gilded tower with Freddy Douglas!

I, for one am not interested in calling anyone names. I think others concur.

I deal in facts and what people do. ( less what they say )

So far, this administration has ruled by edict and offered many things that may or may not be lawful. ( let alone moral ) In so doing, they have declared Democrats as obstructionists to any dissent of said edicts. There is a process and there are parliamentary procedures. republicans used them for the entire Obama Presidency and now balk if they are used now.

Reporters, pundits, columnists should deal in those facts and actions as well, to give a fair accounting to the American People.

Including you.
userLocation: This is what you voted for people (at least a minority of you)

commentBody:
The Dems should put a hold on any Supreme Court nomination until Trump releases his tax returns.

It is really the only leverage they have at this point to gather this vital information shedding light on possible conflicts of interest.

The Constitution is silent regarding the number of justices--the original court having six members. The current Court is functioning fine with eight members, and will certainly continue on with a diminished membership.

I relish the thought of my Senator Schumer standing firm with folded arms demanding the tax returns, declaring "I'm prepared to wait until hell freezes over!"

Welcome to Team Trump!   Need something anarchistic, anti-semitic, islamophobic, or simply cruel?..., Bannon will roll out of his cardboard box and write you a doozy.   Need to assault a woman rights, denigrate the LGBTQ community and condone it all in the name of his lord and savior JC?....then Pence is your "dude."   Need to spin some alternative facts?....Kellyanne and Spicer are more than willing to make your head explode and do it with withering smiles and grating voice.   After all, it takes a village to support the village idiot.

Oh, Gail. How can you manage your wonderful perspective and sense of irony? You almost make me think that there is hope that we may survive the next four years. Maybe even, you give hope that the rascals in Congress can be voted out in two!
Thank you. I was just about to blow my brains out with frustration over what's happened in the last 10 days.

This tendency to differentiate Trump and Republicans has to stop. They are one and the same. They are liars, greedy, short-sighted, money-grubbing, criminal parasites on the land. They are going to self destruct. When that time comes, the Republicans are going to attempt to throw Trump over the bridge by pointing to the differences between them. Don't give them ammunition. They are one and the same. The Republicans nominated him and elected him because he is just like them. They are the same. They are destroyers of our system. They feel they are above the law, just look at the poor job of vetting they are doing on their patronage jobs. Disgraceful.

Yes Trump and the Republicans are bad for America because they are one and the same and their vision is anti-American. They are both Ugly-Americans.

In regard to canine breeds mentioned here, there is a saying:
"I would say civilization has gone to the dogs, but that would be an insult to dogs."

Thus, the new Trump/Pence United States "civilization" we wake up to.
Yes, please do not insult dogs.

I guess my vote would be (B) Save ammunition. Trying g to block this nominee would be fruitless in the end and seem like childish retaliation over the Obama nominee. Dems need to be realistic, they are not going to get a liberal justice.

Doesn't it seem that Trump thought Frederick Douglass was still with us ? Someone clever should set up a Twitter account for Douglas, and start tweeting away.
Trump's appraisal of the great abolitionist may change when he gets some insulting tweets.
Douglass could then be put in a category like, say, Alec Baldwin's.
It might be a better choice to tweet, rather than talk on the telephone, with the Australian P.M.
But Trump would probably figure out a way to argue using smoke signals, too.

A recent study of human evolution suggests that our ingenuity and science has pushed our life expectancies well passed the age of forty. The scientist who proposed this theory mentioned that forty was to be our maximum age according to recent evolution theories. I'm sure Gorsuch, the originalist has carefully scrutinized these theories. He's a thoughtful man who can certainly help our president and his heaven centered VP solve our difficult aging problems, and their co-joining issues.

Social security, federal pensions, Medicare cause a great deal of concern to our financially prudent, no new taxes, (especially for the rich) administration. Besides, blunderbuss sales might go through the roof and really stimulate the economy. However, there is one detail to iron out. The Whigs supported modernization and congressional power over presidential power. Trump might have been impulsive. But, he can always change his mind.

A heroic effort, Gail, and consistent with the acerbic wit we love and value from you. Yet, it's hard to make light of this circus by Pence's Pomeranian (there, I cast my vote).
Gorsuch is not Trump's nominee. Trump doesn't have a clue what the SCOTUS does. He is a flaming ignoramus.
Adding the Pomeranian's piddling on the Australian Prime Minister's leg in the latest news cycle; exacerbating the alienating of Merkle, May, Nieto, Trudeau and completely tone-deaf response to China while sucking up to Putin, it's hard to know how his debut on the international stage could get worse. But he does by repeating the performance on the domestic stage! We can only speculate how it could be worse...and Melania isn't talking. All I heard was "It's a small matter...of no consequence."
Donald Trump is the Howdy Doody on Pence's lap but the script is being written by Bannon.
I opt for filibuster and forcing Yertle the Turtle to invoke the nuclear option. It will pay great dividends to the Progressive Movement in 2018 and 2020...assuming we haven't been incinerated.

When Trump advises Mitch to take the "nuclear option", he thinks he's showing off his macho domineering and intimidating side. Actually he's just showing his ignorance of the fact that politics is not like the real estate business—a one-shot deal with a winner and a loser. Senators have to deal with each other continually, on many subjects, in close quarters, for their six-year terms. To do so effectively requires tact, diplomacy, and consideration for the other folks' feelings—for which Trump is not qualified even to speak.

These are trying times.  The once great nation is at once reviled and joke fodder around the world becauseof the POTUS.  In the space of less than two weeks he has managed to alienate just about everybody not in his party.  Allies are scared of his erratic and dishonest behavior.  And then Ms. Collins returns to inject a little wit into the situation.  I will sleep a great deal better tonight, but I fear the morning news will set me off again.  Thank you, Ms. Collins.  We need youo.

Trump seems to have done all the right things in choosing Gorsuch as befits someone whose ex-wife claims he read really effective ways of destroying democracy at bedtime. Schiclgruber's father 's adopted family name stands the test of time as Trump's true mentor, second in line only behind Breitbart's Bannon. Woe betide we Americans as we follow the latest war monger as he threatens more and more countries like Mexico with war to get his way.

Good stuff dudette! Your animal analogy has one more good thing going for it: it's a limitless source of inspiration for the rest of the Trump cabal: Deer (in-the-headlights) Kushner? Badger Bannon?

Equal parts Animal Farm and Animal House.

Whatever nickname you come up with for Trump as part of this dynamic duo, I'd like to suggest Bobblehead Pence for the other half. Ever notice how this veep can't help himself every time his pet says or does something that conforms to his misogynistic and xenophobic views? Cheney at least knew how to hold his puppet strings more discreetly.

Well now that President Trump has hung up on our Prime Minister and tweeted nasty, stupid stuff about a deal our government thought it had with the US, even I plan to crawl under the bed. I mean, there are only 24 million of us but we have been loyal allies and this is the thanks we get. I doubt Pence was involved in this one.
So before I crawl under the bed, Dudes, I am going to write to our Prime Minister and suggest he close Pine Gap.
Sorry Gail but this is what happens when you don't have compulsory voting.

309 days. That's how long the Republicans in the senate had to act on Merrick Garland's nomination while President Obama was in office. Since the Republicans in the Senate did nothing about Garland, I suggest the current Democratic senators wait 309 days before considering Neil Gorsuch. That schedule would make it Dec 6th before any action were taken. Just in time for the winter holidays!

Remember Trump's advice to the Senate about Garland: "Delay, delay, delay". It would be sweet justice (pun intended) if his own words came back to haunt him.
Pence's Putinian Plush toy
Pence's preposterous preening Pomeranian, without doubt.  And no mention of a rooftop car trip?

Look. President Obama's designated power to nominate was usurped for partisan ends. This is, by definition, a nomination that serves the Republican, rather than the public, good. Any judge who accepts this nomination is embracing, morally & legally, the politicization of the court.

There's no such thing as "saving ammunition" for a later nominee. The Republicans don't acknowledge law or argument in their pusuit of power; they won't now, they won't the next time. But principle & integrity are not pyrrhic, even if they are defeated by power. Any consideration of this and future nominees by Mr. Trump (excepting Merrick Garland) is a betrayal not only of the constitution, but of us, the people who can longer have faith in the independence of the judiciary.

But lap dogs have some endearing traits. The president has none. More likely it’s Pence’s job to power up the hydrogen fuel cells in the Trump-1000 every morning and make sure that the metal endoskeleton is completely hidden underneath the suit.

"I'm sorry, you cannot pick C." Not fair, Gail, that was my first choice! Seriously, every morning I get up, turn on my computer and have a look at the New York Times before plunging into my work -- and every day it just gets worse and worse. After 8 years with a dignified statesman in office, now we have "Pence's pet"--obviously not housetrained--tearing through the White House, chewing up the constitution and anything else he can get his paws on, whilst Republican leaders (McConnell and Ryan) stand smirking in the background, apparently oblivious to the wreckage.

I love your writing, Ms. Collins, but I think even you are having a hard time trying to find the funny side of this "administration." Oh for the good old days of Mitt Romney with Seamus on the roof, that was always good for a smile. Trump has only been in office for 12 days, and I personally see nothing to smile about.

Ms. Collins, the president's pet is none other than Steve Bannon, a rabid pit bull who the president has unleashed last week when the unconstitutional ban on Muslims and the demonizing of Islam was announced. Yes, Mike Pence is the VP alright, but Bannon is the drill sergeant who's the muscle behind this White House's policy. He put the national news media on notice when he told members of the Fourth estate to "keep its mouth shut", a bullying tactic that his boss must have assuredly approved of. Bannon's not taking any prisoners going forward, and his alt-right base couldn't be happier.

Ms. Collins, I have noticed, with growing discomfort, that most every photograph that the Times runs (well, not "every," but you catch the drift) displays the groomed and smirking face of Mike Six-Pence. Not six months ago I was dismissive of the Indiana governor; I thought his career over as he resigned his office to ride shotgun to His Orangeness. I remember thinking "this guy might have trouble finding a job in January" after the Madame Secretary cruises to the title. So much for reading the tea leaves.

Trump is a disaster, yes, but he's insane. Pence isn't insane, but he's an even worse disaster because he is (gee, what)? He appears in all the roll-out pictures, you know, the announcements of the new administration. It's kind of like a nurse wheeling out an invalid to make sure the patient doesn't do anything disastrous while taking the air. I've used the "d" word three times, so I guess I'm trying to make a point.

Trump had no more input into Judge Neil Gorsuch than I had. Can one even imagine the vulgar vulva-grabber-in-chief even taking up a sheet of paper with more than a paragraph? Those Doug Mills photos the Times runs that show No. 45 holding up executive orders with his flatlined graph of a signature are mere show. The new president has probably never read a book from cover to cover...unless it was, oh, Alice In Wonderland.

I fear that Pence is the brains of the outfit and Stephen Bannon is the viscera. Trump would be, umm, the spreading rash.

News bulletin (actually, three of them):

1. Merrick Garland will not be appointed to the Supreme Court.

2. Trump will not release his tax returns.

3. Gorsuch will be confirmed, and pretty quickly, despite "tough" questioning by Democratic Senators.

The Democratic Party has three choices on the Gorsuch nomination:

1. Sit back and do nothing, allowing the nomination to sail through.

2. Oppose the Gorsuch nomination tooth and nail, by filibuster if necessary, but lose and leave many observers (a) noticing that the Democratic Party, despite its strong effort, lost; and (b) wondering exactly why the Democratic Party chose the Gorsuch nomination to fight over, rather than keeping its powder dry for a fight it might actually win.

3. The one the DP will pick:

Oppose the Gorsuch nomination, but not too hard, for fear that the Republicans might retaliate (for example, by using the "nuclear option" to prevent or end a Democratic filibuster), lose, but vow to monitor carefully Gorsuch's behavior on the Court (whatever that means), and try to persuade the public that the DP could have won if it had really wanted to but that it had decided to keep its powder dry for a later fight.

I fulfilled my promises in the first three months.  Aren't I great?"  2) On the other hand, the president may be moving frantically because he (and particularly Mr. Bannon) believes that allowing the country and Congress time to weigh in on issue after issue will insure that less gets done. 3) Not even Donald Trump can keep this pace up at age 70 for four years.  He could quit after one year out of boredom, having kept "all my promises." "(So what else is there to do but that boring governing stuff?  After you've changed the world, that's quite a comedown.  Pence is good at that kind of stuff.")  4) He could try to keep up the pace and collapse. Will he let some distinguished US Army doctor do an annual physical and report on his condition, or hide the results, like he hides his tax forms?  Something could go wrong, if he pushes himself too much, forcing him to resign, though it's likely he has the genes to withstand the abuse he is putting his body through, especially since he neither smokes nor drinks. Among his parents and grandparents, five out of six lived to 88 or more.  Still, there are plausible scenarios, given his personality and lifestyle, in which he does not complete this term.

" stolen from Obama"

Nothing was stolen from Obama and Blow knows it. All liberals know it as well. Blow and other liberals celebrated Biden in the early 90s when the shoe was on the other foot. Blow thinks readers are fools.

Re the stolen Supreme Court seat and the Gorsuch nomination:
The Dems on the Senate Judiciary Committee should ask nominee Gorsuch, as a strict reader of originalist intentions behind the U.S. Constitution, for his interpretation of Article 2 Section 2 "[The President] shall have Power, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Senate, shall appoint...Judges of the supreme Court..."

Did the the Senate Republicans violate the original intent of "advise and consent" by not allowing a hearing and floor vote on President Obama's nominee or was the Senate acting within their lawful powers as defined by the Constitution by refusing action on the President's selection? If he opts for the latter interpretation, then the Dems should shut down the process immediately as it is within their constitutionally defined powers. If the nominee opts for the former interpretation of the Article, then the Senate Republicans were acting unlawfully and the infraction should be addressed and corrected. "No comment" is not an option.
We won the popular vote, all we need to do it keep doing what we are doing and just spread more of it into the red states.  I say stay the course, we will win this if we do not change.

Mark my words Democrats. I and many others insist that the Democrats categorically reject enmass the nomination of Gorsuch to the Supreme Court and force the Republicans to use the nuclear option. We will find another party that will fight just as dirty and just as nasty. I personally refuse to waste my vote on a party that doesn't have the courage or will power to do what is right and just. As usual, Democrats are trying to play by the rules while Republicans are ripping up the rules. In circumstances like that, you have to punt and make the best of a bad situation and hope the American people are smart enough to keep up.
Linda Selvia

Democrats must not be complicit in making the Republican Supreme Court the graveyard of social justice. The Court is now corrupt and has no more legitimacy than the Trump presidency. Disinfect the benches.

" Make the asterisk president’s nominee become an asterisk jurist, the only one confirmed under an altered set of rules"

In order to protect Obamacare it was Harry Reid who, by using the nuclear option, altered the long standing rules of judicial appointments to pack the DC Court of Appeals. Should we then place an asterisk by those liberal jurists so confirmed?

In the blink of an eye, our world has been turned upside down by a sinister and aggressive cadre of the extreme right. We were asleep at the switch during the election, or were stupid enough to pout over Bernie's defeat by Hillary Clinton, so refused to vote.

Reality is here now, and Mr. Blow is absolutely right in his admonition to Democrats to "grow a spine". This administration is no longer of group of gentlemen who hold different political views--it's a group of bullies who have no rules of engagement--just a burn and slash plan of action.

While Mr. Gorsuch is not a screamingly bad nominee, he is nevertheless a conservative who will steer the Supreme Court in a rigid path of adherence to immoral and regressive policy. We must do everything in our power to block his nomination.

I remember my high school history teacher saying that one of the reasons America managed to win its independence was the British army's civilized habit of marching and fighting in tidy, neat columns. It made them sitting ducks for the snipers and wild, chaotic charges of our forefathers.

Democrats need to take a lesson from that first war. We have to stop fighting civilized and start fighting dirty.

I don't say that lightly. Democrats are all about win-win, and in normal times I would never ask my reps in Congress to obstruct Trump and his junta at every turn. But we aren't dealing with people who believe in win-win resolutions, we're dealing with bullies who get their jollies from watching us lose.

The only way to stop a bully is to show we're smarter, meaner, and tougher than they are -- and that only happens when we start winning our fights. No more compromise -- not until the bullies are willing to work with us for a win-win.

Now is the time for snipers, wildness, and chaos.

Do people really think this is about Democrats not having a spine?! We did not return enough of them to Congress to stand up against this onslaught.  Non-voters and Bernie protest refusers got what they wanted, a crisis to prove they were right.  The crisis does not vindicate them, it proves that voting is not an emotional expression.  It's consequential.  And it would not have happened without their failure to act responsibly.  We can't blame officials, the Democratic party, or a "flawed" candidate, it's purely and simply a failure of the electorate.

The intent of the Framers was to escape and prevent tyranny. I'm fine with an originalist who is able to perceive that Corporations and even duly elected leaders with a dictatorial style can amount to the same thing as royalty.

Any entity that places themselves above the common welfare is trying to be a king.

The fact of the matter is that in the end Gorsucks will be installed by the republicans.
My choice of action would be to have hearings during which the Democrats first mention their outrage that Garland did not even get a hearing, and secondly question him on his views on all progressive issues to highlight the things that may come to pass in America if another regressive justice is installed.
And lastly when the Senate vote comes to pass, all Democrats should either not attend or all vote "NO."

As @Teahergal pointed out in a different comments section, no judge with proper character and judicial wisdom would even accept this nomination until Merrick Garland was first voted on. There needs to be pressure on all of the potential nominees to decline to accept , on principle.
In the meantime, I have been persuaded that Democrats do need to obstruct this nominee tooth and nail on principle.

Gorsuch has two daughters who might teach him a thing or two. Throw in the horrors of pregnancies from rape or incest, and even the most conservative father in the world might blanch.

The big question then is, "Is Gorsuch a hypocrite?" We all know the wives, daughters, and mistresses of conservative men who wield money and influence always have a choice because Dan Quayle taught us that.

Hypocrisy may be a necessary "quality" for anyone in the Trump administration. How else could a person stand the dissonance?

Block and obstruct every one of Donald's nominees, just like Republicans did to president Obama.  This seems to be the only language Republicans speak and understand. Trump is the Trojan Horse. Angry words, petitions, marches, editorials help us deal personally with the injustice; but there must be some stronger, bold actions we can do to defend our democracy. What are your ideas? My two senators and representative need to hear them too.

I am beginning to wonder if the breach in this country is now an uncrossable chasm. Not only do opposing sides misunderstand each other, they do not care to try. The Founding Fathers could have never anticipated the damage, but the lack of proportional representation in the senate is giving too much power to a minority, creating havoc.

Senator McConnell in 2014 was elected in Kentucky with about 800,000 votes out of 1,435,868 total. He will do whatever Trump wants based on few voters' desires. The majority of American voters are being terrorized by this local yokel.

This happened over 20 years ago and it has been nauseating watching all the gutless mediocrities from Clinton to Obama grovel in subservience to the frothing liars of malignant intent in the GOP and American right. The Democrats could not, would not beat Donald Trump. Let that level of political incompetence sink in. The establishment Democrats handed not just the White House to a rabid Bircher Republican party, but the states and local governments. Democrats are simply not credible; they champion no one.

I am through with them. There needs to be a party of the people.

Yes, opposing Gorsuch is a matter of principle (although Gorsuch's deference towards religious abuse in our secular constitution, via Hobby Lobby nonsense). Blow sounds more and more like Hillary Clinton. It's all a vast right wing conspiracy. Never mind that Trump was elected with over 300 Electoral College votes. Amen! If the Democrats don't take a stand on Gorsuch they risk becoming irrelevant. If ever there was a time for Democrat Senators to make a stand against this president it's now. Charles, I feel you are a bit overly optimistic about the next four years. Thank you, Mr. Blow, for saying far more eloquently what I've been saying for a long time now.
