THE DEMOCRATS Need to bring a gun to the gun fight going on in the national arena with TRUMPZILLA climbing the Washington Monument the bellow and rage--the spotlight shining on his orange hair, face and peabrain.  Make that pee-brain.  Gorsuch on the Supreme Court would be just another nail in the coffin of the rule of law under the Constitution.

Good job, Charles, agree 100%.
Lets not forget how relentless Trump was in disrespecting Obama in the high office while crying birther. Trump was loud and obnoxious, distracting and such a nuisance. Obama had inherited a terrible economy, two wars, high security issues and this clueless guy just kept repeating birther, show me your birth certificate. He needed to be publicly humiliated at the correspondent's dinner, in the most gentle and subtle way, with the spot light on him, to finally accept that Obama was indeed an American born President (didn't matter that his mother was American to begin with). History books should never forget Trump's role in creating and fanning confusion just because the President was "half black" with Kenyan roots.
If Merrick Garland's treatment at Republican hands is brazenly unlawful, then this nominee is illegitimate. He should be treated as such.

I agree that the Gorsuch nomination is the fruit of a poisoned tree: President Obama's nomination of Merrick Garland should have been acted upon by the Senate in 2016. It is unfortunate that Democrats did not fight the GOP's action then.

I recommend that the Democrats treat the Gorsuch nomination as an opening skirmish for the 2018 and 2020 elections. This is a "minds and hearts" issue: how should the Gorsuch nomination be handled so as to maximize Democratic support in the next two election cycles? I don't pretend to have the answer, but my guess would be that opposition is needed, rather than acquiescence.

As for hopes that the GOP will accept a future Democratic filibuster on a future Supreme Court nominee if Gorsuch is seated without a Senate fight: there is no evidence to support this thesis, and much evidence to suggest that it is wishful thinking.

Perhaps the best way forward for Senate Democrats is the WWMMD Plan: What would Mitch McConnell do?

I agree, for now the Democrats need to send a message to Republicans that we plan to fight.  It would be too discouraging for all the fired up activists who want to oppose Trump for the Democrats to simply give in.  However, Democrats need to mobilize over the next four years.  They need to take back not only the Presidency, but also the House and the Senate and then they need to really work to fix government.  In part by changing norms into laws to protect the democracy.  Presidents should have to disclose tax records and sell off business holdings.  Supreme Court Justices have to be given a vote when a president is still in office.  Executive orders have to go through certain vetting procedures before being foisted on people.  The Democrats have to take back control and then restore order. Republicans are taking us down a very dark path and Democrats need to start working now to win in the next two elections.

Yes, Charles Blow, the seat on the Supreme Court was stolen from President Barack Obama 9 months before he left office two weeks ago.  Antonin Scalia died in February 2016, one year ago, and the Republicans refused to hold hearings for Justice Merrick Garland for nine months.  We understand but don't agree with you that Justice Neil Gorsuch nominated by Trump is "an "instrument of the enemy".  He is just the unlucky but brilliant justice who is now waiting for Trump's majority advise and consent of the Senate to affirm his nomination to the Supreme Court Bench. Opposition by Democrats to Justice Gorsuch's nomination won't be tit for tat as the Republicans, by using the "nuclear option" can ram through any of Trump's nominees they choose to. Gorsuch was the "Hobby Lobby" Justice.  So much for his conservative extremism. This is the way the cards lay, even if we the people don't like the hand we've been dealt by a TV showman millionaire con-artist and narcissistic 45th President and his pit-bull attack dog, Steve Bannon.  The mid-term elections are the only chance the Democratic Party has to even the score.  And by mid-term elections, maybe President Trump will decide to move on to more financially fruitful fields of endeavor. Trump is the "Fruit of the Poison Tree".   Your wishful thinking - that Trump's frantic pace indicates a man whose time is running out - may be prescient.  How long can a 70 year old man (with physical and psychological ills) keep up the frenzied pace?

I agree with Mr. Blow.  I am a Democrat who wants my Congress men and women to get tough and oppose this nomination and every nomination and bill from what is possibly an illegitimately elected president.  Russian hacking is just the tip of the ice berg in this ridiculous situation.  It is possible that this election was bogus on a number of levels, but we won't know that unless the Democrats demand and get the investigation that will actually bring to light just how corrupt this election really was.  To get that investigation, Democrats will have to be as obstructionist, unrelenting, and demanding as the Republicans have been for the last eight years.  Now is the time to get started.

You’re right: the extremist left will fight the nomination of any JUDGE, because they don’t want a Court compose of judges, but a Central Committee composed of commissars. The left passionately rejects the notion of a judiciary independent of politics, demanding, instead, an expressly politicized body which arrives at foreordained, hard-left results.

Judging, done right, is inherently conservative; it involves applying the facts of a particular case to the existing law, given to the judges – often a very long time ago – by the people or their representatives.

The left will have none of that. It demands, instead, that the judiciary impose leftist dogma, simply making up the law as it goes along, ala RBG.

Ideally, the politics and ideology of a judge ought not to matter, as the language of the law should mean the same thing to everyone. But, alas, the left simply ignores the text and history of the law when it precludes leftist results. And results are all that matter.

So, for instance, when a judge looks at the language of the Constitution, and asks, “where do you find abortion”, the left responds, “who cares? No Constitution which fails to protect abortion is worth having, so it MUST be there."

The left demands a judiciary which imposes leftist results by ukase. And the law be damned.

Which is why no leftist ought ever be permitted anywhere near a black robe. They simply don’t understand the job description.

I disagree. The standard is review and consent. Yes, the Republicans misused the process for their own gains and the Democrats should extract a price, but not obstruct the nomination of an otherwise qualified justice.

But the key is what Gorsuch does. I think he should roundly criticize the politicalization of Supreme Court nominees in his opening statement. Say that he accepts the nomination but that if Merrick Garland isn't nominated for the next seat under this administration that he will resign. That would be consistent with his position and settle this issue and bring back some civility to this process. But calling the other side "enemies" is something we could leave to President Bannon and Mr. Trump.

In other words, Blow says use Gorsuch as a poliitical ping-pong ball, in retribution for the Republicans' dirty tricks. Make a show of liberal strength. Punish the Republicans. They did it first.

It's been clear for some months that Blow is enraged, has lost his perspective, and is now blindly devoted to opposing all things Trump, and maybe all things Republican. Sorry, but I can't support either party playing this way, and I don't want my representatives doing so. I want them doing their jobs, even if they had a bad election.

It looks especially petty to keep blaming the election outcome on the Russians. Early in the election, polls showed Hillary could not beat Trump (though Bernie could). Dem superdelegates and Debbie Wasserman Shultz chose this candidate for us, and short-circuited the primaries.

Let's get back to governing, and let the Republicans be known as the party of nasty tricks. Ultimately, they will be rejected.

So the Republicans' second President Asterisk of the 21st century, the first having been appointed not elected by the Supreme Court, appoints a justice who will fill a vacancy that only exists because of another Republican abuse of power. I don't know that stonewalling this appointment will be effective but I DO believe the Democrats should use the hearings to remind the man that the Court has power only insofar as it maintains its legitimacy in the eyes of the nation--that's the way it was designed--and he is joining the court as Justice Double Asterisk.

Time for Democrats to channel a little Churchill:

We have before us an ordeal of the most grievous kind. We have before us many, many long months of struggle and of suffering. You ask, what is our policy? We can say: It is to oppose... with all our might and with all the strength that God can give us; to oppose an incipient tyranny, never surpassed in the history of our nation. That is our policy. You ask, what is our aim? We can answer in one word: It is our democracy, democracy at all costs, democracy in spite of all bullying, democracy, however long and hard the road may be; for without democracy, there is no survival. Let that be realized; no survival for the United States, no survival for all that the United States has stood for, no survival for the urge and impulse of the ages, that mankind will move forward towards its goal. Let's take up this task with buoyancy and hope. Let us feel sure that our cause will not be suffered to fail among men and women. Let is claim the aid of all and say, "come then, let us go forward together with our united strength."

There are few things more futile than merely gnashing one’s teeth that a bigger sibling has control of the TV remote and prefers professional wrestling to C-SPAN. Instead, figure out what leverage you possess to gain for him OTHER things he wants, and apply it in trade to regain control of that remote – at least PARTIALLY.

Liberals are being led astray by those like Charles who see no real exit from the box into which they so mulishly placed themselves, and counsel mere ”resistance” that EVERYONE knows will be without serious effect. But, then, Charles isn’t charged with making a difference to our governance and Members of Congress ARE so charged.

Just get ON with it.

Democrats haven’t grown too soft -- nobody in his right mind accuses Chuck Schumer or Nancy Pelosi of being “soft”. What they’ve become is ineffective, at ALL levels of American governance. Time to fashion the arguments and SELL them to enough Americans that will get enough Democrats elected to again take partial control of the TV remote. So far, you folks would be justified in cashiering ALL of them for their abysmal failure to do so, regardless of the pyrrhic “feel-good” of their impact-free “resistance”.

“The civility and decorum with which government is supposed to work”? …?!! Under Harry Reid and Nancy Pelosi?! Giveth me a break, Charles. In the absence of real arguments, winners don’t simply cede to depression … they fashion new arguments and get back in the game.

I endorse Mr. Blow's evaluation of Trump and his Republican enablers, but I cannot agree with his tactics. The respect shown for the current senate rules for approving SC nominees strikes me as unjustified. Those rules are not enshrined in the Constitution, and they make our government even less democratic than does that charter. If the election had turned out differently, moreover, Democrats would have discovered the virtue of the so-called "nuclear option." A narrow Democratic majority in the senate would not have permitted the Republicans to defeat a SC nominee of President Clinton.

Far more importantly, the "scorched earth" tactics recommended by Blow would inflict damage on our institutions. If the Democrats oppose Judge Gorsuch primarily as revenge for Republican tactics in the Garland nomination, or because they credit unprovable claims that Putin engineered the election of Trump, they will further undermine public confidence in our system of government.

If they find Gorsuch unacceptable because of his philosophy, then they should reject him. But to oppose his nomination for reasons wholly unconnected with his qualifications corrupts the advise and consent process. The way to avenge Republican misdeeds in the Garland case is to defeat them in the 2018 elections.

I'm a lifelong, progressive Democrat who firmly believes that we "live free or die" with our Constitution.  Mitch McConnell and his Republican Senate colleagues clearly violated their oath to the Constitution when they refused to provide its mandated "advice and consent" for former President Obama's nomination of Judge Merrick Garland to the Supreme Court.  I believe the Democrats must show their base and the nation that they will stay on the high-road and provide their "advice" and their "dissent" over an extremely conservative nominee in Neal Gorsuch put forward by an extreme right-wing, ultra-nationalist President willing to use extreme political tactics (aka "go nuclear") to get his way.  That means, the Democrats need both to make a forceful, convincing case to the nation that Judge Gorsuch is way out of the "mainstream" beyond even Antonin Scalia, and, keep their frightened, vulnerable colleagues like Joe Manchin and Heidi Heitkamp from breaking ranks and thus denying the the 60 votes necessary for confirmation.  Such a principled and heroic, but lawful, stand will show that its the Democrats that have both spine of their convictions and the courage to follow the Constitution and uphold the "rule of law."

I admire Mr. Blow for his tireless and principled opposition to all things Trump, and this column is no exception. I hope it is being read by Chuck Schumer and both Senators from my state, California.

Gorsuch must be opposed simply because the Republican Senators refused even to allow Merrick Garland a hearing. Whether the battle is won or not is irrelevant; the opposition is what matters, because it is based on principle, and the Democratic Party lost the last election at least partly because it abandoned some of its principles.

Trump is a medievalist. He sees himself as our king, his GOP allies are his liege-lords, and those of us who opposed him are simply peasants who must be suppressed. Women are more like property than people, and their bodies must be regulated by their men.

Unfortunately for Mr. Trump, this country was founded on ideals that came out of the Renaissance, the Protestant Reformation, and the Enlightenment. This country will not go backwards.

Anyone but Merrick Garland qualified for a Supreme Court nomination should know enough to recuse themselves from this one. This is a tainted appointment that if installed will forever degrade our democracy. It was a questionably legal/constitutional play by Republicans to turn the Supreme Court into another political arm of the party in power at the moment. It will forever taint the judgment of our highest court and call to question the fundamental separation of powers of our constitution. Qualified Supreme Court nominees should know these are more important principles than their personal advancement, or that of a likely corrupt political party.

Hear, hear!

In granting Gorsuch his hearing, every Democratic senator should ask him for his interpretation of Article II, Section 2 of the US Constitution, which grants the president the power to appoint justices to the Supreme Court, and imposes a duty on the Senate to offer advice on such appointments. Yes, the Constitution gives the Senate a right of veto over judicial appointments, but the clear implication is that this refers to *specific* appointees, not to any and all appointees a sitting president might put before the Senate. To behave as the 2016 Senate did and decline to give a hearing to *any* Obama appointment clearly subverts the intent of the framers.

If Gorsuch is the originalist he claims to be, he must acknowledge the unconstitutionality of the Senate Republicans' actions. It cannot have been the framers' intent that SCOTUS vacancies can be filled only when the president and the Senate majority belong to the same party, but if the 2016 precedent is allowed to stand, that's exactly what will happen. The Senate majority will always act to hold Court vacancies open until the next election in hopes that their party's candidate will take over the White House. If Gorsuch declines to accede to this argument, he's a hypocrite. If he does accede to it, he will have acknowledged that his own appointment is illegitimate.

Put the SCOTUS nominee through the standard process. That is no historical aberration. Don't let the most vengeful voices run the show--yet. Mr. Blow, however articulate, is within that angry silo. His views are understandable, but perhaps not in the best long term interests of the party or nation. What will be in our interests are the elections in 2018 and 2020 (where electoral maps are redrawn).

In over 50 years of having the vote, I have never seen Congress so dyspeptic. Part of that is modern communications, including social media--but that will not go away. The ability to disseminate insults with a hair-trigger will remain in place. Does Mr. Blow think McConnell will not go ahead with the "51 vote rule"? Is this seat really worth a showdown, or should that wait for the next one?

Does either party's congressional representatives have the capacity for substantive forgiveness at this moment? It is not immediately evident. Can Congress dial down the tension when that is not what either base wants? None of our congressional "leaders" appears to have that sort of strength.

I am a Democrat and we are partly culpable for our difficult position. We lost support across a broad swath of the country--we can't demand that CA, NY and a few other places rule the nation (we can, but it would not perform well as a tactic to get us out of this mess). Trump looks like he cares more about his base than the nation. It has been less than two weeks and we have a long ways to go.

The greater insult is not that the Rs stole this nomination from Obama, but that McConnell said, when it looked like Clinton would win, that they would not fill this position for the next four years. I have no idea why the Ds in the Senate are not raising this.

On the other hand, Gorsuch is no friend of the Chevron doctrine of judicial deference to agency interpretation of their statutes. This might be a good time for the court to show some restraint in applying this doctrine to the Trump's agencies.

Also, if Trump fails to serve out his term, we would be dealing with President Pence, who would likely insist more than Trump on right-thinking judges. It's a close call, but I'd rather the appointments of a someone trying to establish an oligarchy than someone trying to establish a theocracy.

Mr. Blow, always eloquent, a voice of hope and inspiration.

Gorsuch is the bitter fruit of a poisoned democracy. Republicans have been poisoning our elections (suppressing voters), poisoning civility in government (shouting "You lie!" to President Obama), poisoning government itself (government is the problem, shutting down government, hurting the public because they could not get their way).

In a poisoned democracy, Democrats must recognize the antidote is not wishful thinking, it is action, opposition, steadfastness. Never give an inch! Democrats who reach across the isle will only have dirty hands.

Now is the time for all good Democrats to come to the aid of their country.

"I say let them. In fact, make them. They are likely to confirm this nominee anyway. What liberals don’t want is to have Democratic fingerprints on this political crime scene. Make the asterisk president’s nominee become an asterisk jurist, the only one confirmed under an altered set of rules."

With the disaster that seems to be coming in the Trump administration,the above quote from Mr. Blow's column is the important one.
The nuclear option is coming and in the long run that will work for the majority of the country that believes in democracy.
Make sure that no democrats have fingerprints on cooperation with this administration.
The most important thing to remember is that President Trump was elected by 24%of the voting population.
We democrats must get out the vote for the mid-terms.

Gorscuch showed a willingness to be part of Trump's exaggeration universe. He said he'd served on a court that covered 20% of America, but added "and 18 million" people." I wondered if he counted gophers and rattlesnakes among his charges. But the stark numbers do point to the influence of the Big Empty on our elections. Otherwise, we know well that Trump exaggerates his numbers. The latest I know of is the 1,250 refugees from Australia that Obama agreed to review: Trump tweeted that they were "thousands." Surely this kind of lying must impact on Trump supporters eventually?

As for the confirmation of Gorsuch, the Senate Democrats should demand hearings for Judge Garland before Gorsuch is considered. I wonder where that man gets his ethics that allow him to smile and take a stolen seat? All his judgments are hereafter suspect.

The judge disqualified himself by admitting that he is against abortion, assisted suicide and a host of other issues, which he has pre-determined to be against or has decided what is best for supposedly free citizens in a democracy.
A judge is supposed to be a person who listens to the arguments on both (or more) sides of an issue and determine, based on the arguments and the constitution as amended, who has made the most cogent arguments and choose the one who is closest to being correct. If a person already decided before he hears the case, how can he be fair or in any way said to be Supreme. If Grouch is made a member of the court, the American people have been betrayed and the judge is a suspect in treason against the United States.

The  Rs changed the Senate rules last year when they refused to perform their Constitutionally mandated function of advising and consenting to a Presidential appointment. Time honored and ensconced traditions of compromise and consensus were throw out.  Now it's time for another rule change; the Senate rule requiring a super majority to approve a Supreme Court nominee has outlived it's utility.  Rules that encourage compromise and consensus have no place in today's political environment.   They work well as gatekeepers when all the cats are in the corral, but can't herd the cats into the corral.  There will be no immediate effect of moving to a majority rule; Judge Gorsuch  will be confirmed regardless.  But, the change will pay dividends as voting demographics change and will make it possible to better resist future SCOTUS appointments during the reign of DJT.

If there was a fog over the election, it was lifted by the leaks. We learned how the DNC, while claiming impartiality, worked to squash the campaign Saunders.  We learned more io what Clinton really thought from her emails  with Podesta. None of that has been even  hinted to be fabricated. Add to that, we found that the emails not turned over were not 30,000 but closer to 300,000. So who ever hacked the emails didn't lose the election for her. If anything, it was he own words that sunk her once the fog wes lifted by the leaks. Gorsuch should have the same opportunity. The committee that holds hearings will have both parties and we can believe that the research by the Democrats would just love to have a few juicy emails. In any case it should be his own words that sink him if he is sinkable. Those words may be found in his rulings as well as in answers to tough questions by the committee members. We have to remember that Trump may have the opportunity to name a second justice if Ginsburg retires. This is an opportunity to establish a fair and reasonable pathway to the court.  Otherwise. the blockage might be seen as peevish obstructionism.

This government, this illegitimate president, is unhinged. And, as we do with a door that's come unhinged, we need to replace it. That should be our goal from this day on. Not try to work with these psychopaths, (I use the word in its clinical connotation), never pretend that this is a functioning Government. America is better than this.

The first step is to wrestle together a coalition, beginning with the Tea Party members as they peel away from this mad core of fanatics. They will. Believe it or not, many of them want much of what the left wants, and common ground is the only way out of this mess. Remind them that the Tea party was a protest against exactly this sort of tyrannical domination. Remind them that they're better than this. Many of them are.

Then the Libertarians, who can occasionally be seduced too, by reason.

A coalition is our only hope, and it will work.

Then we have to work every minute for the replacement of this government, legally, peacefully, and firmly. Now, not in four years.

The most powerful man on the planet can barely compose, let alone speak, a simple subject-verb-object-period sentence. He no more studied Gorsuch's writings than I have pored over the original printing of the Gutenberg Bible. Bannon and Pence are the most likely culprits here, and under Bannon's sway especially, Trump is the marionette in this performance.

I put Gorsuch's odds of confirmation in the high 99+% range. We have a spineless, gutless, lapdog Senate when only the Republicans are counted. And a bunch of girls armed with pillows at a Friday night sleepover as their opposition. At least, that's been the case so far. The protest/mini-riot at Berkeley last night will not happen, though a variant of that event is needed, if not inevitable at some point, in the Senate chamber.

As for the House of Representatives...oh, please. Things are even worse there. It's been 13 days and still a bill of impeachment has not been introduced. What are they waiting for? Trump to kill someone on the floor of the House and walk out scot-free? Just as he said he could do on 5th Avenue and no one would do anything about it. So far, no one has proven him wrong in that self assessment.

Has there been a day since the inauguration during which no protest against Trump occurred? Berkeley last night should be our wake-up moment. Stop things now, and do it in Washington, not in the streets. 1968 will seem like a playground name-calling contest by comparison.

We may have a would-be king as president, but let me quote an actual king (okay, a fictional one) by saying that this way madness lies. One must -- mustn't one? -- accept reality. Toward what end is this suggested behavior directed? Republicans do not need to be taught a lesson, or not in this way, which in any case they will certainly fail to learn.

Gorsuch merits a fair hearing. This isn't negated by what transpired with Garland. If Democrats allow hysteria to dictate their actions, and their words, polarization, already elevated by appropriate concern over President Trump's authoritarianism, will reach a crescendo. If reflexive opposition takes root, as it did during the Obama years, the likelihood of Trump doing serious injury to the Republic -- with the backing of a rubber-stamping GOP fed up with and enraged by the Democrats' obstructionism -- seems greater, not lesser.

To become the enemy is not to defeat him but to become him. It is better for America for the country to function as close to normal as possible during the Trump years. There are many things that President Trump has done and will continue to do that have been and will continue to be worthy of unyielding opposition. Nominating Gorsuch to the Supreme Court isn't one of them.

Perfect, Mr. Blow. Required reading for Democratic "leaders." A few points:

1. Regardless of his political and personal leanings, his education, and his bench record, Mr. Gorsuch displayed his lack of integrity by allowing personal ambition to trump integrity. No nominee with integrity should allow him or herself to be used in this fashion.

2. "Democrats have grown too soft. They are still trying to fight a gentleman’s war in the middle of a guerrilla war." Boom! Protestors and leakers are leading the way. Democrats need to feed off this growing popular energy, work with it and, if they can, provide a single leader for it. Democrats remain fractured. Time grows short. Indignation and unrest are finite, and the Trumpites are counting on its dissipation in the near future.

3. I completely agree and have opined that Trump will seek an out before his term is up, but only if the popular heat and cleansing light of public exposure continue. He'll have a "medical emergency" of some sort, perhaps another bone spur. His proven habit is to bail after he's extracted as much personal value and wealth as possible before everything comes crashing down like a bankrupt casino and while he can, at least in his own mind, shift responsibility to someone else to clean up his mess or deal with his outright failure. Trump needs to be sure to retain the EPA, that congress now threatens to abolish, because his mess will require a hazardous waste superfund cleanup.

We have been run by neoliberalism for quite some time. Be clear. Most governing by both parties has been with this over riding goal. Now we have elected a fascist possibly, but most definitely a tyrant whipping up nationalist sentiments among the disaffected. Democrats were not so soft as they were simply on the same side as neoliberalism. Their progressive wing was not. The progressive wing lost. Now we have Trump.

What bothers me most is the silence of people who voted for Trump, despite their claims the they are not racists, they are pro-women, they believe in the Constitution, they support freedom of speech, etc. etc. etc.

Trump does not listen to us. He probably won't listen to them, but they at least have a chance of getting their voices heard. They should stand up and shout to their Senators and Representatives that this is going too far.

But they are silent. Racism, hatred, and assault on our freedom all thrive in an atmosphere of silence.

The Republicans own it. Let them break it. The Democrats should do a jiu jitsu maneuver on them and let the GOP crash and burn. Why haven't they destroyed the ACA yet? Where is the import tariff? Come on man! We need to shut down the flow of goods coming into the nation. Empty the shelves at Walmart. Why is Medicaid still operating? It's been two weeks. Where are our vouchers? And what about all those factory jobs for rural red state America? Has any ground been broken yet. All we see being built in the countryside are wind generators. Everyone know those things are a useless waste of money. Climate change, what a joke!

Give us more religion. Give us more guns and in more places. We need more guns because if there were more guns, then we could get the terrorists before they get us. We already have more guns than people and we can see how well that has worked out. If we had more guns, we wouldn't have to screen immigrants because we could shoot them on the spot. Just like they do in Iraq where the whole place is at war.

We are at war with ourselves. The Democrats haven't realized that yet. Like they say, all's fair in love and war. The Republicans live by that motto.

It's very unclear what Trump is really about, but someone suggested in another venue that he not only ordered the ban on people entering from those several countries but also has ordered their ambassadors and families home. This suggests imminent military action. Trump may be working on starting some more wars real quick before Congress or the public can even blink. That could explain what's behind his frantic pace of orders, etc.

"This seat on the Supreme Court was stolen from Barack Obama"

Yes. It was stolen by McConnell, long before Trump was candidate, while McConnell and Ryan still opposed Trump.

The Supreme Court system is broken, and has been for at least a year, maybe a lot longer.

We should appoint nobody until the system is fixed. That may take years. The Court may shrink to seven, or even its original five, which was good enough for the Founding Fathers. Fine.

Who broke the Supreme Court? I think it was first of all Chief Justice Roberts and extremists like the deceased Justice Scalia.

McConnell's refusal to consider a new Justice for a year was just the finishing touch. Let's go with that idea -- no more Justices appointed until we've fixed the idea of the Court.

They need ethics. We need agreement on selection. "Do whatever they want" and "ram through a radical majority pick" are not good ideas. Do over. Don't appoint anyone until it is fixed.

I am shocked by the mischaracterization of this nominee as anything but an extremist in much of the media.  He's not just "right of center".  He is responsible for the egregious Hobby Lobby decision, which allows secular employers to impose their religious views on employees.  The British press today is full of information about his operation of an extremist publication in his student days.  The American press needs to be more up front about this.  Even our false equivalency loving U.S. media admit he is to the right of Scalia, who is one of the most right wing extreme activist justices in U.S. history.

Confirming Gorsuch because Dems are "fearful" the Republicans might use the "nuclear option" is idiocy. What do they accomplish by keeping the filibuster rule if they are never going to use it for a nominee?

While its possible Trump might try and do away with the filibuster for other legislation, I am not so sure he has solid support from Senators who remember a time not that long ago ('09) when Dems could have done the same thing.

As for Gorsuch--how come there is so little discussion about his restrictive views on a Woman's right to control her own body? Calling this Judge "right of center" is being charitable. Frankly, he is as scary as Scalia if not more so. No Judge with such left leaning opinions would ever be confirmed.

"Democrats want to point to the civility and decorum with which government is supposed to work, but this ignores the fact that government is broken and completely overtaken by the people who broke it."

Great assessment. So the reward for corrupt, broken government is .... cue the drums. ...full GOP control of all branches of government! And cabinet posts so ethnically challenged that it would take months of hearings just to vet one or two.

Which of course isn't being done. I agree, Charles, Demos need to grow a spine as well as a few other body parts. They look and sound meek, like sheep cowering in a locked pen. And while they bray, our government is being trashed by a man so puerile, so belligerent, so unworthy of the presidency who "operates in shadows" as you put it, with full motives still unclear.

Dems need to regain power. And they won't get it by sniveling or being in disarray, They need to get a DNC chair, now. The time for action was months ago.

And stop playing by rules of comity and civility that seem quaint in a White House that has no guardrails.

Do we really need a justice on the Supreme Court with a 250-year old mind set? Whose sense of the law is guided by a time when the material issues of society were far different than today? How can he adapt an unchanging view to change?

This is a typical conservative shibboleth: to put the law above the people it serves. By fixing its existence, the constitution protects only those who granted themselves the original powers built from freedom--limits were intentionally designed to protect the powers assigned to a few and denied freedoms to others. Conservative jurists wrap the law around a colonial model, but real limits—then and now—were imposed upon members/groups within society: women, people of color, workers, the poor were denied participation by a constitution that denied them the vote and any legal redress. The law rolled up the ladder of opportunity; it sanctioned segregated societies, racist systems of violence and political economy, patriarchal misogyny where women were chattel and abused, and workers exploited.

Such was the glory of society governed under original intent! Even the slightest shift in law opens the way for a return of these dysfunctions!

Original intent is a hypocrisy! It is a philosophical frame whose real intent—then and now—is to preserve power. The Senate should vote no on Judge Gorsuch's nomination. His view of the law is inconsistent with progress. He lives in a day surrounded by yesterdays; we live in a world surrounded by tomorrows.

Everything about this new administration is tainted, including the Senate's refusal to consider Garland and the rush to confirm Gorsuch. Changing the rules for political expediency or to deny due process means that every sacred tenet of our democracy is subject to change at the whim of a corrupt administration.

This is exactly what we're witnessing now. There was no precedent to deny Obama's nomination of Merrick Garland. Mitch McConnell couldn't make Mr. Obama a one-term president, so he invented a rule that would minimize his legacy as much as possible by rejecting judge Garland out of hand.

If Democrats cave in to this sort of blatant manipulation of the rules and confirm Gorsuch, then they're participating in the unraveling of our constitutional framework. If Gorsuch is truly an originalist, what must he think the of the unprecedentedly novel way which brought him the nomination? Someone truly concerned about original intent should be hesitant to be placed in that position.

This crew had done more to destroy core American values in less than two weeks, than any previous administration I can think of.

Not only have the EOs brought chaos to our streets and airports, they have made our country, our stated ideals, the laughing stock of the world.
These actions have lessened our global power and our spheres of influence, while validating the deepest fears of Muslims worldwide, while validating extremist ideology.

That 45 "won" with 3 million fewer votes than the "loser", coupled with years of Republican gerrymandering and voter suppression, at the same time as allegations of Russian hacking and other improprieties, means there is no mandate for this President. There was no landslide, there was no great outpouring that led to a massive popular vote win.
Tainted. This presidency is tainted.

That Republicans have obstructed, obstructed, obstructed and bragged about not confirming Obama's nominees, bragged about keeping him from implementing policy although they had nothing of their own to offer.

Our elected Democrats better wake up and listen to their constituents or they are all out of work in the next go-round. And they better toughen up fast.

Among other things yesterday, Republicans voted to allow coal companies to go back to poisoning rivers and streams without penalty.
Need a cool clear glass of water? Too bad. That's been privatized.

"Because the lives of your children, and ours, just might."
Have no fear, Blow, the environment will get to our children long before this justice has a chance to do damage for "generations".
There will be NO generations the way Trump is headed.

"...it's not clear to me he wants to serve out the term." Throw out your old playbook; public opinion is meaningless when polls are meaningless. I do not mean they do not matter to us, rather they should not be used as a barometer for how tRump views the longevity of his presidency.

Democrats need to fight Judge Gorsuch nomination to the Supreme Court.
The Republican Party cannot be trusted! They stole Obama's pick to the Supreme Court, which was really a pick for the Citizens of our Country that elected Obama twice. Republicans Senators failed to do their Constitutional duties and give Judge Garland and up and down vote. During Judge Gorsuch hearings Democrats need to remind this Country that Judge Gorsuch's nomination to the Supreme Court is illegitimate! Let them end the filibuster, they would have done it anyway, for this pick and future picks. Gorsuch was nominated because he is the choice of the 1% and Corporate elites. The Republicans party is poisoning the institutions of this Country. They have poisoned free and fair elections via Gerrymandering, and interstate cross check. They are a party filled with hate and bigotry.

Charles, even if Trump does not want to serve out his term - now that he is finding out that being President of the United States means working like a brickie* amidst lots of criticism and scrutiny -, Bannon will make him do it if he ever can. He could not find a more "useful idiot" (to employ a term invented by Bannon's idol, Lenin) to carry out his sinister agenda if he would grow someone in a lab.

*Hibernian English for bricklayer.

Blows columns are repetitive. We get his dislike of the trumpeter, from day one. Here.s the prob. With certain foreknowledge that each succeeding column on the trump presidency will be just another vituperative exercise, why bother to read it. Try for an original idea, for example.
Agreed...if the Senate Democrats value a real democracy, a "line in the sand" must be drawn!!  But, I'm not optimistic - most of them appear to be spineless.

Thank you Charles.  There is no normalizing the Trump administration and doing so just gets us a little bit closer to brown shirts and goosesteps.  Yes Democrats must resist at every turn just as the populace must resist at every turn because if we don't resist now there may be no way to resist in the future.

Yes!  I contacted my government representatives yesterday and everyone needs to do the same.  Be angry!  Let them know you do not approve of this appointment because the seat was stolen from President Obama and the values he represented for us.   And, yes!  Let's show our soft representative what we want!  This appointment is a seminal one in our history, we must make every effort to stop it.

Democrats must fight all the way. As Mr. Blow writes, "tooth and nail". We must never, never, never give up. We must fight like our lives depend on it because they truly do. Repealing the ACA alone will leave uncountable thousands to die prematurely. That's not to mention the nuclear bomb that the evil man in the white house intends to drop on Iran.

When you get hit, you don't just hit back. You must make sure that you do not get hit again. You knock 'em out.

The only nominee we should approve must be Merrick Garland. Or none.

Within two years we will win back the senate, maybe even the house. And possibly the presidency, with Patrick Leahy as president pro tempore being in line for succession when Trump and Pence are arrested for crimes against humanity.

Of course, the Republicans will portray any fight against Gorsuch as naked partisan politics. The best stance Democrats can take is to prevent Gorsuch's nomination from coming before a committee for exactly the number of days that Republicans blocked Obama's nominee. They need a clear slogan to send this message: Gorsuch 350 -- or whatever the number is.

I do not think there is much chance the Dems will not oppose Gorsuch. Or any of his nominees for that matter.

Opposition is the nature of politics and marriage.

Democrats should force Mr. McConnell to implement the nuclear option to elongate the process and further register contempt for this illegitimate administration. Mr. Trump is an asterisk president and Mr. McConnell is a shameless politician who deserves to have his legacy permanently shackled to the buffoon who now occupies the oval office.

Republicans should be forced to publicly clarify the new rules which they made up and then shamelessly acted upon for Obama's nomination of Merrick Garland.  At what exact point, according to the new Republican rules, is it appropriate for the Senate to refuse to hold hearings?   Under the new rules shouldn't we wait to see the will of the people? After all, Trump has low approval ratings and he lost the popular vote, and it is not unreasonable to  think the face of the Senate will change following the next election.  Even before consideration of Gorsuch begins, the Republicans need to spell out the exact time frame in which they believe it is legitimate to  shut down the consent process and explain exactly how they arrived at this arbitrary date.  If we are operating under a new set of rules everyone should know them ahead of time.  Of course the right thing to do is to appoint Merrick Garland.

This is not some silly fight about some rules of the Senate. This is a fight for the soul of the country. We are seeing a band of criminals who believe they are above the law (Republicans) take over the levers of power through deceit and unconstitutional means. It is up to the Democrats to speak up against and vote against these parasites whenever the opportunity arises. They need to keep the pot boiling with citizen demonstrators for two years. These citizen demonstrators are our countries immune defense mechanism against fatal diseases. They need to register voters every day for the next two years. They need to send these new voters to the polls and throw the bums out in 2018 and take our country back.

Cut this Republican cancer out of our body politic before it kills us.

Senate Democrats who voted to confirm Justice Thomas many years ago are directly responsible for every Supreme Court case where he has since cast the deciding vote. Today's Senate Democrats should not forget that.

We know from the last three presidential elections that the Democrats have a popular majority in the US. The filibuster is a prop of conservatism; without it the GOP will be severely weakened in the long term.

Democrats need to remember what Trump has forgotten or probably never accepted; we won the popular election. We have the majority wind at our back, and that wind is getting stronger with each mis-step of the Trump administration. They need to keep reminding everyone of that fact as they stall and oppose every Trump initiative until the mid-term elections.
As to the "nuclear option"; the most cynical, calculating politician in Washington, Mitch McConnell, is not going to be enthusiastic about giving up the court filibuster if he believes the Republicans may be heading for minority status in 2018. After that election Trump may well be looking at impeachment if his train wreck of a government continues at the present pace.

Trump actually looks like a man on the verge of a nervous breakdown and I mean that in all sincerity.

I agree that it is time to engage in the Republican initiated gorilla warfare. The US has seen its democracy downgraded to a "flawed democracy" by the Economist. This has been evident for years. Gerrymandering, Citizens United, abuse of the filibuster, government shutdowns, legislating from the bench rather than from a moribund and irascible legislative entity are all evidence of a democracy in trouble. The Electoral College, while the law of the land, is acting to delegitimise democracy by marginalising the majority of the voters. The winner takes all, first past the post system has worked to polarise the government to the breaking point.

At this point, in most Western democracies, there would be a call for a second republic with a new constitution. Now I know this is nearly impossible in a country that elevates its constitution to the same status as the Bible or the Koran. However, it is clear that radical change is required and probably can't happen without inflicting serious damage first. The Republicans have been making a good effort at this. The Democrats need to join in. When trust has been eroded to the point we see today, no amount of tinkering will improve things. The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over and expecting a different outcome.

Good point about Trump's oddly furious pace, which was counterproductive, for instance, in the immigration edict.  But Gorsuch as an instrument of the enemy?  That's the mindset of a reflexive hater, which, incidentally, is a losing strategy politically.  That truth might eventually dawn on Mr. Blow, but apparently not in the foreseeable future.

Any argument is won by one of two ways;
1. Win the argument by arguing a point of view and swaying opinion by merit.
2. Change the argument

republicans are absolute masters of number 2. ( pun intended )

All of them are going before the cameras ( generally familiar and friendly ones ) while espousing how Democrats are holding up the will of the people, Hypocrisy at its finest on display.

The key is that republicans have become emboldened by the fact that they were not held responsible or punished at the ballot box for essentially filibustering the last year of President Obama's Presidency. ( let alone the entire 8 years )

Keep in mind that republicans' constituency ( a clear minority mind you ) generally are spoon fed fox news delights daily ( or equivalent online ) and think that everything is Democrats fault anyways, There is no reasoning with the brainwashed.

I concur that Democrats should stand on principle and vote no to any nominee brought forth by republicans, since they were the ones that initiated this impasse.
userLocation: This is what you voted for people (at least a minority of you)

commentBody:
I have a hard time believing that Judge Gorsuch and his wife were anything other than appalled by President Trump’s behavior throughout the campaign or ended up voting for him. I also have a hard time picturing them wearing Make America Great hats. Or sitting down next to Trump and his adult sons on a bus.

When hope is scarce, you take it where you can find it.

And after all, Ted Cruz himself said that we would do fine with only 8 justices, and many Republicans threatened that if Hillary Clinton should be elected, we could easily manage with 8 justices for her entire term. Why not simply give them what they said they wanted on this?

The "liberal base" is a collection of hooded arsonists, campus squatters and anarchists led by an aging socialist and a bay state crone and egged on by an unhinged, untalented writer for a failing major daily.  Their antics will of course bring about the opposite they riot for.  When that happens, their next stop will be the prisons.  And those inciting them, some resident at this paper, can also be charged with violating laws now on the books.  That too will be cheered by the "pod of trained seals".  We are overjoyed at Mr Charley telling us so!
Well said, you changed my mind. Make this the last stand.
This is the best article I have read since the election. Charles, you are not only eloquent, but right.

Once again the Democrats stand for spinelessness. Interesting how the GOP, for all their chicanery, stood as one in defiant obstruction of President Obama, while the Dems separated into Red state and Blue state. I suspect they will continue to do so under president* Trump as they undermine the resistance.
Democrats do you hear this?? DNC are you getting this? The base is way ahead of you on this and that's not right. We need you now Democrats = Fight like the future depends on it!

When McConnell said Garland would never be considered, he changed the rulers. There's no going back. He won. War has been declared. The Democrats have no choice but to fight back as ruthlessly. There are no norms left to preserve any more. The filibuster must die or the Republicans must withdraw Gorsuch. Either alternative is better than the Democrats giving the Republicans what the Republicans will  NEVER give the Democrats. This is a heads, "I in," tails, "You Lose," moment. Time to say no!!!!

Sorry to inform you but we are no only far past a gentleman's war or even a guerrilla war. For 8 years Republicans have been fighting a scorched earth war and its time Democrats realize that with the Presidency, Congress, and the Supreme Court now firmly in the hands of the lunatics they need to do the same.

I find little difference between today and circa 1933 Nazi Germany and we know very well what happened there when people did nothing.

"...Democrats should look at Gorsuch as an instrument of the enemy."
Sic (!). The "enemy"? "Fight like your lives depend on it". Politicians? Politicians of all ilks and parties firstly fight for their political lives.

Mr. Blow, you cannot condemn Republicans for a certain type of behavior and then advocate the same behavior for Democratic politicians and then come out smelling of lilies.

When one begins a war, even a political war, one cannot be certain of the outcome.

Charles Blow just keeps pouring it on; no let up on Trump from him.
And that's fine, it may not make for compelling punditry, but blowing off steam is a human trait. Mr. Blow provides the valve.
I myself have pondered Trump's longevity. If he remains unpopular and the Democrats manage a strong showing in the mid-terms, he could just up and quit. All while boasting how he shook up a system that proved unamendable even to his greatness.
I disagree with Charles Blow on all issues, but I'll gladly team with him to hold the door open for such an ignominious exit by Trump.

Oppose everything (except infrastructure spending unless it comes in the form of tax breaks to corporations).  The democratic/progressive base is finally in fit fighting mode, they've been pushed too far, and elected democrats better take them seriously.  They demand no appeasement with this administration, these republicans; and least of all with respect to this stolen seat.  This seat represents a denial of the two majority elections won by President Obama.  This seat represents the denial by republicans of the value/legitimacy of the votes cast for President Obama.  The denial of this appointment represents the metaphorical slap in the face to President Obama we suspect republicans really wanted to actually do.  RESIST!
Spot on! And regarding that "brilliant" rollout, The Daily Mail is reporting that Gorsuch founded the "Fascists Forever Club" while in prep school.

There needs to be pushback simply to acknowledge that this nomination was stolen from the previous president. There needs to be acknowledgement that either a president's candidate will always be given a full hearing and vetting or that the GOP's precedent has permanently poisoned the process. And they will pay the price forever.

This is an opportunity to heap scorn upon the GOP, and nothing should be held back. Use an argument that captures the high road (the Constitution over GOP petty politics) but fight it out using every means at your disposal. Maybe Democrats will stop wondering why they are still being bullied, and instead, becoming worldly wise, will find something they will go to the mat for. There are millions of stupid and uninformed voters in America. Time to hold your nose and stop at nothing to get at least 10% of the idiots back into the fold. Trump and the GOP stop at nothing to diminish and demean any opposition. Time for payback.Time for a street fight on principle for a higher cause. Stop assuming voters will figure it out on their own. Tens of millions of them need a puppet show to get it. The GOP assumes they are stupid and us successful. We should too. We are living in an idiocracy.

Mr. Blow, it was Mitch McConnell and the Senate Republicans who employed the "nuclear option" last year when they denied President Obama's nominee, Merrick Garland, even a hearing for his nomination to the Supreme Court. They changed the rules to suit the GOP agenda and they reaped the fruits of victory last November. This wasn't political hardball, it was outright extortion of a Supreme Court seat that the Republicans have no right to fill.

The Republicans have complete control of the American government, the executive, legislative and shortly, judicial branches and their convenient changing of the ground rules to suit their agenda has encouraged an egregious abuse of their power. All Americans are in the coils of the Republican anaconda that is poised to swallow us all.

"...it's not clear to me he wants to serve out the term."

If only this were true. Even setting aside all the opportunities for personal and family enrichment he will have served up to him on a silver platter for the foreseeable future, this is a man whose vindictiveness and paranoia know no limits, and there are so many more "enemies" (journalists, lawyers, judges,diplomats, union leaders, scientists, actors and on and on) to be chastised, and that's just on the domestic front. Add to that list entire countries,( friendly or not,) ethnicities and religions and it's clear that four years will hardly suffice to punish them all for being non-believers.

I suppose he might implode or burn out before the end of his term- I just hope we don't.

It was said that Trump may not continue with the presidential debates if he fares poorly in the first. Then they said he may not really be interested in being President and may back out if he wins. That he may not be interested in serving out time is wishful thinking. He has stated that he will be around for eight years and he means it.

We can not accept a 2 party system where 1 party plays by the rules and the other does not.  I have been saying this since Gingrich turned congress into an investigative arm of the right-wing media.  I was saying it when President Obama let the Republicans hold the country's credit hostage to political demands.  I no longer know if the Democrats are afraid, or if they are collaborators.

Unfortunately, the idea that Trump feels his future in politics is limited is probably just wishful thinking. Likely Trump will keep signing whatever craziness Bannon hands him.
If Trump was fully in control of his administration, I would take the flurry of edicts as a sign that he wanted to get everything done in the first week and spend the rest of his term watching TV in Trump Tower. But the people in power around him have agendas which won't be fulfilled until further and more drastic action is taken.

Once again Blow's hysterical rhetoric undermines his arguments (which are often faulty to begin with). I believe Trump's election is a disaster for America and the world. But Gorusch is qualified to be on the Supreme Court, and a scorched earth battle to prevent his confirmation will fail, and pointlessly waste political capital. This is a time to choose battles intelligently, not adopt some empty slogans to "fight every act of Trump as if our lives depend on it" Some acts of Trump will be serious threats to America. and should be fought against vigorously. But labeling every act of Trump as a mortal threat or illegitimate only serves to weaken the case when his acts are in fact dangerous. A standard Republican conservative joining the Court is not such a case. Oh, and Charlie, according to predictit, the Republicans have an 84% chance of retaining the Senate after the 2018 elections. Don't fall into the trap of imagining that a massive scale liberal revolution is imminent. This is a time for intelligent and informed opposition, not for overheated rhetoric and wild fantasies.

I have to agree, Mr Blow.  I've been going over this in my mind again and again.  The Republicans didn't do their job in the first place, and really, they acted pretty seditiously throughout Obama's tenure.  It's all about party politics, and toeing that line, isn't it?  (I can say that about both sides, really, but the current situation is clearly over the top). Toeing a line that has fast become the Let's Make a Deal With the Devil Show.  Indeed, the people will if the Dems won't.

It's a rare day I disagree with Mr. Blow, but I don't see any percentage in Democrats fighting a fight to the death over Gorsuch.

Gorsuch will be confirmed. Republicans have proven, time and again, that they will do anything - anything - to cling to power and implement their agenda. Gorsuch is nothing more than a pawn in their game of chess, on which they will gleefully rearrange the pieces to suit their desired outcome, while brazenly insisting that the Marquess of Queensberry posthumously endorsed their new rules.

Democrats must firmly express their opposition, of course. But they can't win this fight; their energies would be better spent on one they can win, i.e. making Republicans irrelevant by taking filibuster-proof control of the Senate in 2018.

The hapless Democrats handed the Senate to Republicans in the last election. They can howl all they want about Gorsuch, but the only way to truly win the war, not just this battle, is to take back the Senate in a very big way.

Trump may disappear before the end of his term, but that only means puppet-master Pence takes over. Democrats need to hope for the best and plan for the worst. And the best plan, to me, is for them to be in a position to give the middle finger to Trump or Pence on an even bigger scale than the Republicans did to Obama.

2018 is the key to minimizing the damage. THAT is the fight that must be fought to the death.

Ah, Mr. Blow, if we were living in an actual democracy, Mitch McConnell, the author of our broken government, would have been turned out of office by the good people of Kentucky when he was on the ballot in 2014. No such luck. But he's only the the sparking fuse that snakes towards the waiting powder keg.

I don't remember a huge outcry from the center, leave aside the right, when McConnell severed the knot that binds the three branches of government together. The Jefferson Davis of the 21st Century splashed acid all over the Constitution and none of the Republicans in either the Senate or the House as much as objected. McConnell's un-Constitutional prerogative went way beyond "one-term president" and Joe Wilson's "you lie!" McConnell's denial of the president's lawful rights went beyond his mere hatred of the man whose hue reddened McConnell's face for eight years. In his secessionist rage, McConnell said, in effect, that the underpinnings of government that we've come to know for a quarter of a millennium can be tossed overboard because the president is not a white male. What other conclusion can be drawn? And the "respectable" senators, Hatch and Grassley, and many others less so (Cruz, Rubio, Cotton, Ernst--the list is long and undistinguished) bought into their Majority Leader's treasonous anti-American coup. And much of America yawned.

Billie Holliday's Strange Fruit, indeed. It's also Emmett Till's mutilated corpse grinning across the American judicial landscape.

Sadly, democrats have never shown much of a spine while their GOP counterparts never seem to waiver from their laser like focus on an agenda dedicated to further enriching rich people, stomping on poor people - particularly if they are minorities and making sure every pregnancy is carried to term (and then enacting policies to make that family's life as  tough as possible).   The incredible cruelty, hate. Ignorance and vindictiveness exhibited by Trump and his supporters is overwhelming. Sesame Street is doing a k is for kindness show in our town this weekend and all my kids see on tv is an orange monster and his supporters who never seems to learn this word.  I keep thinking about how this must be similar to Rwanda in the early 90s or Cambodia under Pol Pot when neighbors suddenly turned and began slaughtering each other. And trump and Bannon are ready to strike the match.

Charles, I'm beginning to wonder if any of the intelligence agencies are investigating anything at all.

The Bannon/Trump team may have put the thumb on any snooping - sure seems like James Comey and Rudolph Giuliani certainly have no reason to stop smirking about anything these days.

This coup that is unfolding before our eyes is using the Nazi playbook verbatim to create shock events and disorder on a daily basis. And it's working quite well!

We lost control of the Executive Branch on January 20 when it was infiltrated by illegitimate thugs. And we have probably just lost control of the Judicial Branch as well; Jeff Sessions is part of the shrinking inner circle WH cabal that is sowing discord, and snowballing exponentially.

Do any Republicans in the Senate and House have the guts and/or brainpower to realize we are doomed within months? Possibly weeks?

A little help here, anyone?

A persuasive argument, since the Dems tried eight years of civility and statesmanship, and that period in our history is fading much faster than our collective national mental health can and should tolerate, so yes, the corporate capitalists class  and virtually every new federal hire will be Trumpists-- there is no "honeymoon period," attempts at appeasement, or negotiation with Trump. There are only winners and losers, and negotiation defines losers for GOP knuckleheads... so yes, fight on.

Previous column you called him a "literacy-lite, conspiracy-chasing, compulsively lying bigot (and) also a narcissistic workaholic"---I think that caught it. He's here for the duration because it's fun for him to always be in the limelight; everything he does is center stage. So, while I hope you're right in today's column in saying he might have no "eye trained on longevity"--I think it's rather his peripatetic, desultorily lunging nature that we're seeing, not anything as optimistic as some kind of preparation for the exits.

Should Gorsuch get a hearing the first question should be - as a jurist and self described "originalist" - does he think the GOP handling of the Garland nomination was legal? Legitimate? and accordingly how does he view the legitimacy of his own nomination as a result.

"Nothing is more common than for a free people, in times of heat and violence, to gratify momentary passions, by letting into the government, principles and precedents which afterwards prove fatal to themselves. Of this kind is the doctrine of disqualification, disfranchisement and banishment by acts of legislature. The dangerous consequences of this power are manifest … and establish an aristocracy or an oligarchy … Let the people beware of such Counsellors. However, a few designing men may rise in consequence, and advance their private interests by such expedients, the people, at large, are sure to be the losers in the event whenever they suffer a departure from the rules of general and equal justice, or from the true principles of universal liberty. These men, not only overleap the barriers of the constitution without remorse, but they advise us to become the scorn of nations, by violating the solemn engagements of the United States."

A Letter from Alexander Hamilton to the Considerate Citizens of New-York On the Politics of the Day (New York, 1784).

Instead of building a wall to protect us from Mexico, we could build walls around the top 10 economic metro areas across the nation and let the republicans outside the walls figure it out themselves - a la Lord of the Flies. They could debate white 'victimhood' between watching reruns of Duck Dynasty.

I agree completely with Wilkinson that the imposition of Trump's anti-democratic policies on the more liberal populations of U.S. urban centers will do great harm to the nation. It's clear from the left's reaction to the early days of the Trump administration that the people are willing to vigorously oppose governmental action that is contrary to the long established values of the nation. Values that were once held dear in the heartland that now endorses Trump. I wish I could be more optimistic that the feckless Democratic party is up to the challenge of bridging the gap between the urban and rural populations. With the recklessness and willful infliction of chaos by the administration, I fear that unification may occur by default when Trump causes an international crisis that spirals out of control resulting in armed conflict. When the price of supporting Trump comes at the cost of dead and wounded U.S. service personnel, most of whom come from small town America, perhaps then his supporters will reevaluate their position that Trump can do no wrong.

Great article. In the election, the Democrats proved Edsall’s thesis by focusing on post materialist issues, while hewing to more conservative fiscal principals to protect their wealth.  Hillary Clinton was their shinning avatar. By embracing postmaterialism and turning their back on economic issues they underscored that the party was no longer “of the people,” and more “of themselves.”  In the primary the Democratic Party threw Bernie Sanders, a crusader against economic inequality, under the bus.  And when the dust settled and Clinton had won, she and the party flushed Bernie’s ideas down the toilet. Then, the party went back to polishing her crown in anticipation of her coronation. Corporations, big banks, and the financial sector have conspired to create vast profits for themselves, and consequently, to drive the country apart economically. Trump and Sanders were the only candidates that indicated any sympathy with that reality and its ramifications for the average person.  Sanders was sincere.  Trump was a con artist.  And the result? Well, as the man said: “There is a sucker born every minute.”

So Trump got elected and the Republicans have control of EVERYthing. (Except the majority of voters, but that's clearly not worth all that much.)
Here's an idea: run against Trump's "peculiar" populism with a platform that is genuinely populist, and unambiguously pro-most of us.
Not pro-job.
Not pro-industry.
Not pro-growth.
Talk about the need to explore 21st century solutions for 21st century problems: Green Energy, Basic Income, Universal Healthcare.
Dispense with the public-private partnerships. Stop shoehorning "market solutions" into everything. Look people in the eye and tell them that "innovative financial tools" is code for "gambling" and admit what we all know: Wall Street bankers are mostly immoral a-holes. Reject the narrative that the way to get people back on their feet is to bribe employers to hire them at starvation wages.

Okay, call me a lefty-liberal-elite if you want, but I don't get it.  Was it we LLEs who destroyed unions?  Funny, I seem to recall some guy named Reagan doing that.  Was it we LLEs who reduced taxes in a way that benefited upper income people at many multiples of any benefits going to the lower and middle income groups?  How many people remember that it was Reagan who destroyed our progressive tax system.  For two or three years during his administration, there were only two income tax brackets, a situation which vastly benefited the rich.  Is it the LLEs who keep trying to do away with the estate tax, something that applies to less than one-tenth of one percent of estates--that is, to the estates of the richest of the rich.  Is it LLEs who believe that corporations are people, so that their huge amounts of wealth can be used to support political campaigns against the interests of we, the people?  Is it LLEs who quickly ended any funding for retraining for displaced workers?  Is it LLEs who inserted tax breaks for the wealthy into the stimulus plan rather than money for projects that would have put people back to work?  It's true that the Democrats frequently fail to fight sufficiently strongly against the efforts coming from Republicans that hurt we ordinary people, but they are NOT the ones who introduce and support all these policies that hurt 99% of the population.

"In support of this argument, the authors point to 2016 exit poll data showing that Hillary Clinton won voters who said the economy was the most important issue by 11 points, 52-41, while Trump carried those who said immigration was the most important issue facing the country by nearly two to one, 64-33."

Why? Because lazy scapegoating and fervid resentment born from an unearned sense of entitlement that is foremost race based are much easier reactions to changes in circumstances than seeking to contribute to actual solutions. And we're supposed to have sympathy for these folks? Seriously? And somehow the blame for this surrender of thought must be laid at the feet of so-called "postmaterialist values" rather than the decimation of unions, the greed of companies taking full advantage of a new global environment, not to forget the wholesale ingestion of trickle down voodoo economics by the majority of these said people. Please.

The average income of Trump voters is $71,000!

This populism is not led by the working poor but by the middle class whites who want :

More white's Less Browns - More natives Less immigrants More Bible -Less science and reason More freedom Less progress AND most of all comfortable emotional alignment with a boob in charge kinda like THEM!

CEOs of nursing homes get wealthy while the people who change the bedpans eke by at wages barely above the minimum (if that) and no benefits. America First takes us back to pre-WWII isolationism, before we learned the harsh lessons of Pearl Harbor and a hot, perilous war. At that time we were vulnerable, lacking military might and alarmed, and when we joined the fighting, a lot of our young men were dying. Under these extreme pressures, all political and ideological differences could be subordinated to helping our Allies, building the arsenal of democaracy, and winning the war. That wasn't easy to sell to the Heartland, and the success of that effort created the great America that Trump wants to return to.

Now our wars are continuous but low pressure, and we are tempted to think ourselves invulnerable inside our fortress, and close the doors. Trump may think that we can afford to disregard and weaken our alliances, but the fortress is much more porous now. Manufacturing is worldwide, wealth more evenly spread among nations, and our economy more disruptable from outside. We have benefitted profoundly from having peaceful and collaborative relationships with other nations, and from offering a beacon, however imperfect, to the unfortunate. Now we may discover what it is to lose that advantage. Our problems in part come from having had it too good for too long. Yes, attention must be paid to the needs of the Heartland, but Trump doesn't know history.

One commenter noted that wars have unpredictable consequences because there are "too many variables to factor effectively."

Consider marriage, traditionally an important bedrock of society. I think marriage is in part an ongoing negotiation between prospective or current spouses. But in large part the parameters of that negotiation are set by society. The wider the parameters, the more variables there are to negotiate. When those parameters are in flux, that in itself is a new variable that greatly increases the odds of misunderstandings. Emotions may run high and hot.

I personally don't see gay marriage as a threat to heterosexuals, but it introduces a new variable. I suppose it increases the competition for some potential mates.

To the extent that monogamy is no longer bedrock and polyamory becomes more acceptable, that's another important variable to be negotiated.

The same point applies to more flexible roles allowed by society regarding breadwinning, householding, and child rearing.

The old roles were established over time based, one supposes, on experience, custom and the thoughts of secular and religious scholars.

I agree changes were necessary but I'm not so confident they've been well-considered. I often joke that the women of my generation changed the world when they were sophomores.

People are having to figure this out for themselves as they try to earn a living and live a life.

FDR stated the case well in 1938:

"Democracy has disappeared in several other great nations-not because the people of those nations disliked democracy, but because they had grown tired of unemployment and insecurity, of seeing their children hungry while they sat helpless in the face of government confusion and government weakness through lack of leadership in government. Finally, in desperation, they chose to sacrifice liberty in the hope of getting something to eat. We in America know that our own democratic institutions can be preserved and made to work. But in order to preserve them we need to act together, to meet the problems of the Nation boldly, and to prove that the practical operation of democratic government is equal to the task of protecting the security of the people."

Any other ideas?

This entire discussion of Materialism and Post-Materialism makes no sense. Obviously it doesn't refer to the Marxist concept of Materialism vs Idealism, and if the suggestion is being made that consumerism-- the more popular concept of materialism, the placing of great importance on the accumulation of things-- let up to some degree at any time between WWII and the present one would have to be delusional to postulate such an opinion.

The forces pushing the latter form of materialism have only continued to pick up momentum with each passing year. The mere fact that the act of coming into possession of material has become more difficult as the income gap has widened doesn't mean that those who have not do not want to have. Suggesting that the self-realization movements that emerged from the social transformations in the 60s lessened the urge to consume cannot be taken seriously. There were beads and bell bottoms to buy, and rock albums, and stereo equipment, and posters and VW buses at the very least.

It is hard to read Edsall's columns, since they mix sound statistical reasoning with the kind of unsound, suggestive stats that prompted Mark Twain to comment: "There are three kinds of lies: lies, damned lies, and statistics."

First and foremost is the ever-present tendency to use statistical correlations to suggest causation, as Edsall does when suggesting that the correlation between underwater mortgages and Trump votes is evidence that one is a cause, or "predictor," of the other. (In case you forgot, stable correlations can be used as "predictors" in the sense that if hemline heights reliably cycle at a given yearly pace they can be used to predict other things that reliably cycle at the same pace. But since neither causally influences the other, the word "predictor" is misleading, because it suggests that one is a "sign of" (that is, causally influenced by) the other.)

Note another problem: Being none-too wise about finances can explain the debt-vote correlation. The same basis on which a person puts too much trust in shoddy deals leads to bad mortgages and votes for demagogic presidents.

The point is not that these other suggestions are the correct ones. It's that correlations are being cited as strong evidence of causes when they are not. They are only, repeat: only correlations. Add confirmation bias to the mix, and we have a powerful elixir.
