People need to understand the differences between a traditional "foreign exchange student" and a "foreign academic student".

A foreign exchange student is here on what is called a J1 visa, issued by the State Department and is designated a cultural exchange visa. The purpose of the visa is for the student to share their culture by means of attending a US high school, getting involved with their community and bonding with their host family. Host families are volunteers, not paid. The students are given multiple orientations in their home countries prior to arriving in the US, and have multiple orientations while here plus support thru the organization they came through. There are many safeguards in place for the student and the organization is responsible for the student while they are in the US.

A foreign academic student (like Korbin) comes on an F1 visa, issued by the Department of Homeland Security and is designated an academic visa. The student is here to get an education. Families may receive a stipend. If the student came through an organization (not all do), it is rare that they receive the preparation a J1 student does, or the support a J1 organization offers. The school is the sponsor of the visa and is ultimately responsible for the student while in the US. While cultural exchange can happen, it is not the priority for these students, it's a bonus.

For students who do a true exchange experience, it is life changing. Public diplomacy at it's best.

In my Chinese language class in college, we often read passages related to Chinese Americans' history and role in the community. We learn that in the 1800s, they came for the jobs building the railroad. Most were poor people who tried to make money later opening corner stores and salons.

Then in the 1900s, the Chinese to came to the US are the best engineers and scientists, fleeing persecution during the Cultural Revolution.

Now it's people who got rich too fast and see the world as a place where anything can be achieved with money. Their kids are models of the concept of privilege.

If the US is giving them problems, they will go to the UK, Australia, Canada, The EU and other places which will welcome them... for their money.  We are not the only place where higher education is at its best.

The funny thing is that the white-wright-wing refers to latino illegal immigrants as the ones coming to still "their" jobs...

But, look now who is really coming after theirs and their future kids' jobs....

Maybe it's time to stop winning and force our politicians to do their jobs and provide the means for not a good education, but for an excellent education here in the US.

Too many people arrive in the USA expecting to find life as in American movies.  These companies promoting the American high school experience for foreign students should be providing much more in preparation for real American life, and at least teach them appropriate language skills, including slang.

A lot of these schools hint around that if foreign parents send their kids to US for education that a green card will be stapled to their diploma.  The schools and universities are selling US citizenship and making a buck off of it. Something they have no right to even talk about.

These people are just in America to sponge off of a great system they didn't help create.  Now our greatest universities have basically been colonised.  This is exactly the kind of thing that led to Trump's victory.  America is far, far too open.

This situation is particularly acute in California's Silicon Valley. Lynbrook High School in San Jose has top-performing students in mathematics and science. Wealthy Chinese parents are walking into desirable neighborhoods in this district, knocking on doors, Zillow valuations in hand, and offering families double the value of their homes--cash--to establish residence in the school district. This is repeated all over California.

In regards to the laptop that was "so powerful it blew out fuses in [the] host family's house", chances are the laptop had a bad transformer or the wrong power converter. Most North American countries use 110V electricity, while China uses 220V electricity so he probably plugged in the computer and it shorted out. Even a supercomputer in a high-tech lab doesn't blow out the fuses around it.
Momzers!
16yo, and the mother is still doing the packing for him? Well, that says it all.

A small number of ppl are making a lot off money off these rich Chinese kids.
The rich Chinese kids then take spots at publicly supported colleges, not simply bc of their academics, but bc they are rich enough to pay out-of-US tuition.

Working and middle class kids, who are not rich or advantaged with tutors and often have to have jobs after school, lose out.

Other Americans sell them out for profit and some ppl on this board celebrate that. White kids especially, with no "diversity" points, no pricey tutors, and no money for private schools or out of state tuition lose the most.

It's wrong.
Drives up the cost of private Jesuit high schools that used to be where the working class sent their sons to climb up to the middle class. That avenue has been closed for decades now.

I think it's great to bring diversity and money to public American high schools which are struggling with decreasing enrollments and funding. If done right, American students and families get a chance to learn about the rest of the world, and Chinese students get to understand American values. One of my European relatives did an exchange program in the US and got a lot out of it. But, the dorm and the Chinese student only classes are not a good idea. (I also think the 1 yr visa limit is pointless and stupid) These are kids and they need to be/feel a part of a family. And, there's no benefit to other students if they don't have integrated classes.

Lastly, as an immigrant myself who moved from a large European city to... SC, I can tell you you that the values do rub off. Korbin may consider himself more Chinese right now, but when he goes back to China, he will take back with him an appreciation for the clean air we breathe, and the way we treat companion animals, and he will start asking, "why don't we have that in China?"

Some school districts are losing children due to the higher costs of living in those areas. So they're starting to accept more Chinese students into their public school system. It helps pay for the schools AND keeps the average test scores artificially inflated.
People need to get a grip.  There are hundreds of thousands of American students studying abroad in foreign schools.

The article isn't completely accurate or true as some other readers have pointed out, rich Chinese may have other reasons why their kids are sent abroad. A more interesting question is why local board of eds need so much funding. The boards  already have absurdly (by world standards) large budgets and number of employees. Something in this story doesn't make sense.

If I were Chinese and rich I'd be sending my kids to Europe. I would not want them brain washed and imprinted Ideologically by the influential in our university system.

As for Americans, rich or poor, I would also try to institute some real reform in education. Make it available, decent quality and mandatory. There's really no excuse for everyone not to have the chance at a decent public education.

this is not new.  back in the 90's, I taught at a public high school in SF and we called the Hong Kong displaced students "helicopter kids" - dropped here by their parents, in the care of strangers, left to their own devices, basically abandoned with the same goal in mind as these Chinese kids now.  that was almost 30 years ago ...

As a Chinese-American who emigrated with my parents to the U.S. at the age of seven and grew up through the public school system in Ohio, I can sympathize with the relatively chilly reception received by Korbin and his friends.

It is not so much a language barrier as a cultural - and I would argue, financial - barrier that prevented me from having many (if any) American friends, although Korbin's family sounds far more affluent than mine. But because I understood none of the pop culture references that my peers seemed to relish, especially those from their parents' generation, I was viewed as an outsider. Having packed lunch that smelled funny because we couldn't afford the $1.25 school lunch didn't help. Neither did having off-trend discounted grocery store sparkly pants when Abercrombie was all the rage.

I had become completely fluent in English within two years. All of my friends claim I have no accent today - except perhaps a Midwestern one. And although I identify fully with being American, now, at least culturally, there are still instances when I am confronted with the "but really, where are you from?" questions from those who are likely well-meaning but live in more homogeneous communities outside the coasts.

I'm thankful every day I live on the East Coast in a melting pot of cultures, and that my parents sacrificed much to give me the life I have today. It would be a shame for the ladder to be pulled up behind me because we fear what is different.

For good or ill, a diploma from one of America's tip-top colleges (think Harvard-MIT-Princeton-Yale-Stanford) is the magic entrance card for many elite professions and honored positions in this country. Competition to get in is brutal; every year those top schools could fill their freshman classes (and PhD programs) several times over with fully qualified applicants who are rejected.

Knowing how many exceptionally accomplished American students are turned away from admission, I do resent foreign citizens being accepted into so many of those slots. Harvard's website says that over 20% of their students are from outside the United States. MIT says only 10% of their undergraduate students are international, but 42% of their graduate students are. Revenue for these schools is not the issue, as it is for most colleges, because they have massive endowments.

Frankly, if you walk around these campuses and listen to the languages being spoken, it feels like the percentage of foreign students is higher than the figures being reported. I have no ill will for foreign students, but many hard-working American young people are being denied the golden apple.

I guess the USA is the "Charter -to-the-West" of China. The thing is that if you read the evaluations of high schools across America, you really wouldn't want to send your kids there, so not only are they paying top dollar, they must have also found the TOP schools. Most high schools across the states only manage to graduate 75% and some only about 60% or  less.

It seems to me that welcoming foreign students to American high schools and colleges is a great idea if we can present a good case for our values to them: liberty, equality, justice, etc. If that's what these students are taking out of the experience then, whether they return to their own countries or stay in the US, the US benefits. If all students are taking is the technocratic and financial advantages US society offers and combining that with either an oppressive, corrupt foreign government culture or being totally turned off by a bigoted, cruel, and aggressive American culture, then the US is in trouble.

I think is great Chinese kids get Americanized. We have already exported our obesity epidemic, our disregard for the environment and our popular culture there. Nothing corrodes a society like American culture.   Pretty soon the Chinese will be as fat, lazy , unintelligent and sick as the U.S thus leveling the playing field.
“I also want my son to understand, in a way that I never could,” he said, “that the world is bigger than Shenyang, bigger than China.” That's why the Chinese are eating our lunch.

We have to stop these people. They are putting way too much pressure on me to get educated, stay educated and always be willing to learn. I want to stay stuck in the past. I don't want to change. I also am not willing to do work that I consider to be beneath me. It is these foreigners fault that life is not good for me.

And look at my life. It is terrible. Do you see what is on television all the time. It's junk. It makes me fat. And I am not happy with being fat. And there is nothing to do around here. Except maybe drugs. There were jobs, but they are gone now. It is all the elites fault and the media and the mexicans and everybody else.

It can't possibly be the power elite, a tiny proportion of the population that have gained control of the majority of the money in the world and all of the power that goes with that.

It can't possibly be the belief that the only real participation that is possible in this world to make life successful is consumption, more more more.

It can't possible be that in fact, if you took a quick survey of the world, you would find that we are doing the best. We've got it good. We are very very lucky.

There is work to be done. But blaming the other and wanting everything in the world that you can possibly imagine don't help to make life better for everyone, everywhere, all the time. And that includes you and me.

How about a traditional exchange program, like those run by Rotary Clubs, instead of this type of arrangement?  If it is truly about cultural exchange, send an equal number of American kids to schools in China.

I have a feeling that this "problem" will be solved by President Bannon. What Chinese parent, or Iranian or Syrian or, heh, even German, student at the high school, college or grad school level would even want to study in America now? Travel bans (sorry, "extreme vetting") and no chance of staying to work afterwards? In-yer-face insults, derision, threats? Danger of not being able to return home when Pres. Bannon lights of the sky for his fans with a few megatons? Nah, don't worry.

The abuse of Public Education Tax dollars with this program is not understood by most people. EACH Chinese student here in Oxford is allocated more that $7,500 from the Education Fund to pay for THEIR education. Think about that as you file your upcoming tax return.

Here in Michigan, and in the other states where this type of program is happening in Public Schools, loopholes in the laws are being exploited which enable school district administrators to snatch the per-pupil funding for every foreign F-1 student they take into their school. In Michigan that ranges from $7,700 to more that $13,000 EACH. The district them claims that they are making a profit because they get the tuition money and the per-pupil funding. They then create special highly paid positions to service the foreign students. Ask to see the audited financial statements for the "International Program" and see how far you get. So where does the money go? In Oxford we have:

A Director of International Programs
A Director of International Operations
A International Student Counselor
Special tutors and Academic Support
http://www.oxfordschools.org/departments/oxford_international_program

TEAM 20
Oxford Michigan

People will call me racist for this so let me just preface this by saying it is anecdotal:
I went to a private boarding high school that was 20% international, largely students from China and South Korea. These students were often amazing people and friends, but in some ways they were detrimental to the culture of the school. They're racist: they believe people who are not like themselves are inferior, and are particularly vocal about their attitudes towards back and hispanic students. Their concepts of morality are different: they would regularly cheat on tests in order to achieve an advantage.
I don't mean to say that these students should not come to american schools, as they are an amazing asset and can offer a unique world view. However, there are downsides not mentioned in the article that affect the other students at these schools.

"They fret about the toll competition exacts from their coddled offspring; they wonder if their child’s creativity is being stifled. "

Isn't it more they understand their offspring won't win the meritocratic competition in China - genetics only goes so far - so they send them abroad, where standards are lower and money (at least in the US, not so true for the UK which this article doesn't mention but which also has a fair number of Chinese students) helps to get one in?

I'm Chinese-American, born in the USA, but my parents were poor students who came to the USA for grad school right before the Tiananmen Square protests. I went to a high school that took students from China, and studied abroad (in Australia) in college. The reason I mention all of this is that I think I've a multidimensional view on this topic (except firsthand!).

1. There is a tendency, in my opinion, likely rooted in xenophobia, for Chinese and Americans alike to stereotype each other. For Chinese students, there's either the "cool" ones (they make friends with Americans) or the others who concentrate on studying and tend to remain isolated with other Chinese students. It's easily forgotten, on both sides, that individuals should be treated like individuals without letting preconceived notions bleed through.

I did tend to get closer to Chinese students hanging out one-on-one but found hanging out with them in groups awkward.

2. Likewise, we tend to conflate actions of other country's political leadership to the will of the people. But that's not really the case in either country right now, so blaming Chinese students for the Chinese government is a waste of emotional venting. Students across the world are just trying to do their best to learn.

3. When I was studying in Australia, my identity as an American solidified. I think that's a natural tendency, not something uniquely Chinese. I love Australia, but I came out of it thinking, "Yep, I'm a born and raised American."

For decades, Chinese parents have been sending their kids to American public high schools in states such as California and New York, usually by buying houses in highly desirable school districts and/or sending the students to live with relatives.  Over a couple of decades ago, we knew many of those kids at my public high school by the fancy cars they drove.  I believe there was a biography by a Chinese-American graduate of my high school (and of MIT and Harvard med school) published back then that was very popular in China and made the high school even more popular.

Schools need the money because the ratio of administrators to students in every kind of schooling (K-12, public, private, colleges) has ballooned. The money for all of those salaries (for people who never interact a minute with a child) has to come from somewhere.

On top of that, administrator/bureaucrat salary levels have ballooned as well.

The fix needed is legislation that withhold federal funds from any district/college/etc if the number of non-teachers employed breaches a specific, low ratio. Legislation limiting the amount of money blown on whatever a million vendors are selling would help, too.

American kids are being crushed under a greed stampede at places like UT Austin. It's wrong.

The world is a better place when more people travel abroad to experience firsthand how other people live and learn their language. Marco Polo will be remembered for a long long time for his positive impact on global cultural exchange. Few Americans even hold a passport. JD Vance's "Hillbilly Elegy" is a must read to understand how Donald Trump became the President. His isolationist rhetoric appeals to like minds. Even within USA, those living on either coasts and in large cities might as well be Martians to those living in the rest of American hinterland.

For a Chinese high school kid to spend a year or two in USA, there is not much hope for serious cultural immersion or making American friends. Language is always the biggest hurdle among a long list of barriers. They tend to hang out with other Chinese kids especially when there are enough number of them in the same school. This is not a new phenomenon and it is the same with foreign students from other countries. No question Trump's unrestrained words can only help turn Chinese kids attending American high schools to be more patriotic. All Chinese regard the One-China policy as sacrosanct.

Brook Larmer is tackling a very complicated topic. There are many angles: money, hyped marketing, problems with the education systems in China and in USA, the unpredictable outcome of cultural exchange & brainwashing, xenophobia, etc. It would take a whole book to cover all the complexities. Well done.

So we cant teach our own children, but we can definitely teach Chinese children. I though American high schools were basiclaly falling apart, at least for Americans.

I guess its just all about the money. If you got $40,000 then you get a good education while American citizens starve in trailer parks and go to failing high schools. The only path to success is to be rich already.

I've seen the issue of foreign students from two perspectives. About fifteen years ago, as a teacher in the Seattle area, I started seeing kids moving from Korea and China to the top-rated high school where I taught. As it turned out, many of the parents weren't immigrating; instead, they turned over guardianship to someone living in the district (another family from their area or relatives) so that the kids could get a good, free education in the language and style of our system. It bothered me because the costs for running the schools are paid, in our state, largely through real estate taxes. Many of these folks weren't homeowners and didn't plan to stay and become taxpayers in the future. It was a scam that was effecting the amount of money dedicated to the kids of those who were paying.
The second issue comes with higher ed. Schools like the University of Washington no longer take the B average students. They hold spots for foreign students who pay much more for tuition instead of giving them to state kids. I'm sure it helps subsidize some good programs but Washington State taxpayers help subsidize those programs, too. I'm all for private schools making a killing off students, as long as the students are treated humanely and honestly. Just don't ask me to pay for them to attend public schools only to take their education back to Asia. One thought I've had is that foreign public college students whole be required to work or volunteer in the US for two years post college.

"370,000 students from the mainland are enrolled in American high schools and universities"
Great! Then they can go home and help build the People's Republic of China.
Anyone ever think if that is really in the long term interests of the US....???

I've been hosting international students through a traditional J1 visa program for over 20 years and this article just makes me sad. It's the antithesis of what the "exchange program" is all about. The goal is not providing proving grounds for students to get into American universities. The goal is to promote cultural understanding among our young people. Think that's not needed? I beg to differ, just look at the rest of the articles in today's NYT.

The fact that Korbin came here, and left with no American friends is sad ... and telling. An exchange is a cooperative venture between the natural families, host families, students and the schools ... which should be backed up by the exchange program. These exchange students should not be enrolled in just academics, but clubs, sports, music and theatre. And most importantly, THEY SHOULD NOT BE SPEAKING CHINESE!

One final point, host families of J1 high school students are not paid. Thus, I fully understand why many are disillusioned because of programs such as these.

Why aren't we sending some of our students to Chinese high schools?

I taught full classes of Chinese students at an american university -- they send students by the classroom-full -- and thought that in business, politics, the military, innovation, education, etc. they are learning the best of our system, then adding that knowledge to their own, giving them a huge advantage over us after they go back home. We have the "Everybody else speaks English" attitude toward language, hobbling us in commercial and diplomatic negotiations (there can be an immense hubbub over a comma, a method of punctuation not used in many languages). In commerce and diplomacy, we seem to have an "Everybody wants to do it the American way, so why bother learning what everybody else is doing" attitude. That only works for a while.

This article sound like my own story. I moved to the US at the age of 15 and attended a public high school in Syracuse, NY. My sister and I were the only foreign students in the high school. I tried so many times to befriend Americans but never got the chance. I struggled being a nerd and was called names like teachers pet and my African American brothers calling me Uncle Tom. I went on the college and graduated Summa Cum Laude. Fortunately and unfortunately all the real friends I made even in college tended to be foreigners. I tried to keep in touch with the American friends I made in high school and college but I realized most Americans don't value friendship.

It really is a different culture than what we see on TV. America has a way of making one feel alienated.

So - how should the US kid who lost his place at Penn State to Korbin feel about this?
Should he or she feel that while personally disadvantaged by this "globalisation" outcome, the world as a whole is better off by this result? Should the kid therefore simply swallow hard and rightly accept it as a "loser" in the global macro, just like his or her father or mother or relatives should who lost their jobs and prospects to non-US factories?

Welcome to why Trump was elected, to the chagrin and disgust of the "one worlders".

Is everything for sale in the USA, even a small-town high school experience? This article gave me insight into the anger of the conservative right. In time, the curriculum, then the cafeteria menu, team sports, prom night will be tailored to the highest paying demographic. What has happened to our country?

This phenomenon isn't new --it started in the 80s.  Anyone who's visited the San Gabriel Valley in Southern California over the last 30 years would attest to it.  My high school's demographics changed in ten years from 5% to 70% Asian, and in those days we said "Chinese," which meant "Taiwanese."

It is sad that no US student did not take the oppertunity to make friends with their Chinese classmates, oppertunity lost. To broaden perspectives, sounds like the faculty and administrations at both levels need to work toward not just toleration but inclusion.
Money, money, money...any questions?

Next stop: Americanized names to hide their ethnicity. Asia has higher IQs and raging ambition, not to mention population growth that is rapidly overshadowing the rest of the world. The west has dominated Asia for more than 500 years, but history tells us its past time for a shift.

In southeastern Pennsylvania, Catholic high schools which were bleeding students due to rising tuition now have active recruiters going to China to find paying students.  It's a perfect match--the empty convents and former priests' residences on the campus become dormitories, and the new Chinese students are filling the once empty classrooms.  Added income enables the schools to hire teachers.  It's a win-win.

The very sad situation is that a very high percentage of Chinese students (particularly those who come over in high school) end up not having a good understanding of American culture, even after they spend 2 or 6 years here. A dorm for international students at public school systems is a horrible idea because it isolates them even more from American students. Because there are so many Chinese students on American campuses, they do tend to form an enclave to themselves and many after 4 years of grading college, still have trouble speaking English or having a good grasp of American society. This, of course, isn't true for all Chinese (or international) students but it is unfortunately true for a large portion.

I absolutely understand the frustration of American parents but it seems that their anger is misplaced at Chinese students rather than their local, state, and federal government. Public (and private) schools want Chinese students because they do pay full price tuition, which is often used to subsidize the cost of American students. Public high-schools will cost an international students anywhere between $20,000-$30,000+/academic year depending on the city. Because state and federal funding for K-12 and higher ed has never gone back to the level it was at before the recession, public school systems in particular are relying on Chinese students to offset the cost for their American counterparts. If American parents want to do something about this, write to your legislators

We hosted two different Chinese high school students who were part of one of these programs over the course of a school year  a short time ago. We've had many foreign young people in our home in the past as au pairs and through exchange programs such as CISV. Nothing was more disappointing and frustrating to us as hosting these students. Unlike previous visitors, they seemed to have very little motivation and showed very little persistence in establishing meaningful relationships with peers at the school or in our home. They followed house rules only if it suited them, and socialized only with each other, constantly, through applications like facetime, even in the bathroom.  Despite this, they expected us to solve their problems and give them rides like an on-call taxi service. Separated from their parents to attend English language boarding school, they seemed to have little respect or patience with parental authority and were clearly from wealthy families where they were coddled. While I think that they could really benefit from cultural exchange, the current system doesn't foster this at all. The private Catholic school they attended charged them an exorbitant tuition, but didn't give them benefits it gave all of the other students (free laptops) or provide any additional language support. It was sink or swim academically and very difficult for one of our students to adjust to the language barrier. It was a really disheartening experience and we would not recommend it.

Compare to the white privilege op ed yesterday. The American asian students are now competing with this group of foreign nationals as well. I personally think, out of national competitiveness, that there should be preference for Americans at both public and private American universities; I am torn because there are so many wonderful foreign students who would make great Americans if they [legally] stayed after college. Yesterday's op ed did not allow for comment while accusing US universities of discrimination, but I do want to say that the Chinese parents cited here describing the lack of originality and creativity in China is spot on. Some of the students I interview for MIT don't make the cut because they just do what their parents tell them, even though they do it extremely well. They are often miserable nervous wrecks. I have observed that some later generation Asian and most Indian parents raise children with a little more flair and independence, and they are more successful in life and at MIT because of it. Also, there is a component of Chinese culture that values 'face' over truth; never a good idea in a business setting or in academia. Lying, even to save the other person's face, is a trust buster. I'd rather have someone who tells me that a thing can't be done, or even that it would be very difficult, than to have someone who will promise to do something that they know cannot be done, and then fail later leaving me to pick up the pieces.

It feels like the Times would like the top US universities to admit everyone. Rural students, urban students, poor students, students of color, foreign nationals, Asian Americans, illegal immigrants - is there a group - market segment - that I've left out? These institutions are highly competitive for a reason, and they've been managing to stay that way for generations. The admissions office has a tough job when you can make 4-5 cohorts just as good as the one you admit from the ones you reject. Time for the Times to stop reporting on the slights interest group by interest group. The sun will come up tomorrow if the Ivies Plus just keep doing their thang as they have done.

The head of admissions at the boarding school I attended in PA said that he could fill the entire school of 400 with Chinese students paying full tuition of $56,00+.  When they visit China each year to hold interviews, the hotel is mobbed by students/parents who do not have appointments.  In the UK, private companies are opening "Potemkin British" schools to educate Chinese students.  The reverse flow is but a trickle, so the west is doing something correctly.  The trend has good points- you have to love the kid who is looking forward to education in the US so that he can make new friends.  He will.

This is another example of selling by those who myopically solve problems without a full appreciation of the impact (or worse are intentionally misleading those who fund their existence). I'm referring to the US educators.

There is little to no integration of these students unless there is only one in each school. The moment there are peers, they will cling together and ride it out in a shared bubble. That bubble works both ways: it keeps kids who might reach out to the new kid from doing so, as they feel they have their own network.

The administration in the school will tell everyone who will listen A) we're global, B) we're learning from each other, C) we're obviously a good school if someone is willing to pay to come here from the other side of the world. None of that is necessarily true.

The students may gain access to US colleges in the end, but the Public Schools doing this are mostly looking to avoid reductions in headcount in order to keep from reducing staff. The tuition never covers the "real" cost of the education (on a per student basis), so in effect the local taxpayers are funding Chinese educations. I do believe that most will stay in the US, but suggesting that somehow these kids are delivering positive financial impact is faulty. They are enabling short term resistance to a long term crisis, and adding permanent costs in doing so.
The more the better. Their work and study ethic should serve as an inspiration to American students. I hope China sends more.

You know why those schools are so poor? Because Michigan underfunds them, because people desire tax cuts uber alles. Then we take something that is a common, public education and sell it to the highest bidder. And I do include those religious schools as a common...otherwise why do they get 501C3 not for profit status?
All these schools represent is a playground for wealthy Chinese families at the surrender of our values. Do we require anything of them except money? Will Korbin ever have to Google "Tianmen Square," or "The Cultural Revolution?"

It always amazes me when I observe Asian Americans dominating every science and math competition at the middle and high school levels. The ethnic Chinese, and Japanese students seem to be a leg up on the rest of their fellow American students whenever the sciences are concerned. Until the rest of America catches up we will just be a nation of consumers instead of being a nation of creators.
I assume that they all say the pledge of allegiance and stand respectfully when our national anthem is played.

Bluntly, only struggling private and public schools are enrolling Chinese students in any real quantity. I feel sorry for the Chinese kids and for the communities that feel they have no other choice than to accept this pay-for-play arrangement.

I am very familiar with one marginal private school in the Midwest and one tiny public school in New England that have Chinese enrollments. The kids are miserable, the host families feel taken advantage of, and the academic experience is hampered for everyone. Meanwhile the crooked consultants are making money hand-over-fist and Chinese families are disintegrating.

The next round of this story? Tiny private colleges will be going out of business in the next decade, and their campuses will be sold to Chinese educational entrepreneurs.

Nothing wrong with raising the bar in American schools. I work with many young professionals.  The highly motivated ones almost always seem to be Indian, Chinese. Americans don't have the work ethic these kids do. It's pretty clear.  Quit giving everyone an "A" and get rid of the 10 point grading scale.  Quit dumbing down our educational system to fit the masses. It is killing America.

What it is about the United States? These Chinese students on average will work several times harder than the vast majority of our kids. But if they stay in the United States and have families here, chances are their kids will grow up to be just like the vast majority of our kids and slack off. Maybe it is the water.

It's somewhat sad to me that Korbin didn't make American friends. It takes a lot to go out of your comfort zone and hang out with people who think or act differently from you. The kids he tried to hang out with may have been a little too different. Maybe some nerdier, bookish kids, or even just kids who really just shared mutual interests like sports or some kind of hobby would have been better choices.

It's all about the money and only about the money. While there are certainly meritorious Chinese students, the influx of hundreds of thousands into our University and High School systems is now a $11 Billion industry. It has little to do with fostering diversity and much to do with increasing a school's bottom line.

And when I read about how Chinese students are smarter and more motivated than American Students, I wonder why their Universities are never considered World Class. What happens to all of those smart students when it comes to creating Chinese World Class Universities?

Cultural exchange is a long hallmark of the U.S. Educational system. But that ideal is being exploited in the case of elite Chinese students buying their way into foreign educational systems around the World.
The broader question is why are public school districts in the largest economy on earth so short of money that they resort to bringing in foreign students to balance the books?

An insightful and telling piece. It shows so clearly how dimensional political conflicts become. Both countries are playing chess on a different board than these families and children. It also shows how domestic politics , in both countries, lands heavily on many.
Mr. Larmer has carved out an important place in reporting. He has humanized much of what has been hidden and found , as he does in this well written essay, both shared values and universal human aspirations.

It's easy to see how this has come about. Follow the money.

Big businesses send factories and jobs overseas. They build products cheaply ( aided by currency manipulation, graft and communist control\no restrictions ) and then send them back here. We buy those cheap products sending the money back there. They send the money back here with their children to get that American certificate. ( the gateway to be of status )

The cycle continues as Americans get dumber by not buying local and voting in those that support the above.

Only in America !

commentBody: There are tens of thousands of wealthy Chinese families that send their children to be educated in US high schools and elsewhere in the world. I have met a few of them as undergraduate and graduate school candidates in top Ivy league universities in the metropolitan area. The undergraduate students were typically educated locally and are much more social than what is depicted in this story. I predict that a good majority of these students will not return to China to live and work. Rather, I suspect their parents want to establish a beachhead in the US and to diversify their assets out to the safe haven of the US. Other Chinese students will return to the mainland and enter the ranks of the ruling Communist Party which provide for the security and prosperity themselves and family. There should be no objection to welcoming these students to study here, as there are all sorts of mutual benefits for both countries to do so.

I was in China last autumn, for a month and a half.  It amazes me how hard they work.  The special snowflake kids had better watch out, no room for them in AP classes, none on the honor roll, and ultimately none in top level universities.

If we USA citizens would like to be great again, we need to instill in our children and public education system Korbin's "academic focus, his grade-point average rose to near the top of his class — a 3.96 — and his standardized-test scores climbed just in time for his college applications.... he had gotten into a Top 50 university..."

Supporting by default “Cool kids never study...[and] hazing other kids..." will just continue to reduce our children’s global competitiveness. Oxford has an opportunity to build a top-notch competitive school system to match Korbin's results.

I'm now retired and I've traveled all over the world. I've met friends from all cultures.

Ever place I've gone, people want the same thing, a good life for themselves and a better life for their kids.

To overcome bigotry, we should expose our kids to those from other places at an early age. That occurs naturally in melting pots like NYC or San Fran, but not so much in the rust belt. Programs like this are a win win. We are all together on this Planet. The USA is only about 4% of the world's population. We need to learn at an early age how to work together in spite of our politicians.
Best of luck in your next project. I've enjoyed your EAT columns and will try this recipe very soon. It sounds wonderful!
I love food stories like this.

Loved the story with this piece and the connections to family and roots. I plan to make it sometime, as it sounds delish.
Best of luck in your next adventure.

Thank you for sharing all of your delicious and heart-warming experiences with us! What a poignant last column, encouraging us to appreciate our history with a subtle reminder that most of us come from immigrant stock one way or another. Best of luck on your journey. You will be missed by us NYTimes food readers.

What a beautiful piece. Filled me with nostalgia and a desire to be even more connected to my own cultures, while realizing, as Lam so eloquently states, that I will always be at a remove. Good luck on your next endeavor.

Food is your heritage be it stir fry, knishes, baba rhum,
yakatori, or sukiyaki
ON Hudson between Jane and W. 12 you will find an Italian,
Chinese, Japanese, and Americn style restaurant.
That's America.
Mangia Essen Fressen
You will be missed! Good luck on your next exciting venture.

Thank you for this piece. It brings back wonderful memories for me, someone who first encountered it during college at a tiny school in Lancaster County. Our Mandarin professor hosted us one evening to make spring festival dumplings. But the most memorable, for me, was the simple plate of eggs and tomatoes. It reminded me of a dish from my childhood, stewed tomatoes. But the addition of fried eggs and green onion transformed it into a literal pillow of comfort that I never forgot.
Thank you for the recipes and stories that you have provided here.  I will miss them, but I wish you the best in your new endeavor and will be happy for the archives here.

Thank you Mr. Lam for your thoughtful articles.  Your insights have provoked my thought on how people of apparently little or no connection, do in fact share some commonality, especially in food.  Good luck in your future adventures and stay in touch with us.

Thank you for this article, Francis! This is my favorite Chinese comfort food from childhood, and now I make it frequently for my husband. When I do, I also have to make mapo tofu, my other favorite comfort dish. Love how the sweetness/tartness of the tomato and eggs pairs with the spiciness of the tofu- and both go so well over rice!

The main thing I do differently is I drizzle the sesame oil at the end. I've learned from trial and error that the taste will disappear if used early on. It may depend on type of sesame oil. I use the Kadoya brand which is arguably the best- it's made from roasted sesame seeds but has a low smoke point, so it's best to add it at the end for optimal taste bud happiness. :)

Back in the early '80s -- when I lived with my wife and small child in northwest Beijing -- our friend, nanny, housekeeper Li Ai-yi [= Aunt Lee or Auntie Lee] made scrambled eggs and tomatoes often (though she couldn't have used ketchup).  I loved the dish and I loved her.  Thank you, Francis Lam.

There is an identical version of this dish made in the Eastern European country of Georgia. My favorite aunt-in-law makes a big bowl of tomatoes and eggs and people spoon form it, catching the rest with crusts of lavash, a Georgian bread.  The real secret is putting a good dollop of adjika on the whole thing, a fresh garlic, chili paste. It may be a perfect condiment. Francis you will indeed be missed. I wish you great luck in your next chapter.

My wife grew up in Fujian, and then Hong Kong, in the middle of seven children, and is not a gifted cook--she will tell you this herself, and laugh. Her contribution to our family-of-four's dinner table is something that I would normally call bland. She calls my Western contributions "too tasty." Dinners are a daily yin-yang of delights and near-misses, buoyed by a small raft of rice and pasta.

The one dish she makes that we all quietly competitively chop away at, however, is this, although hers is of the beef variation. Only on New Year's day--a day observed as vegetarian to start out the year--do we do a meatless version. She'll even rise at 630am to make it to tuck into our daughters' school Thermoses, and then turn around the same evening and make it again. While she has never explained any family anecdote or history surrounding the dish, her silence and our furtive hoarding it onto our own plates suggest that it grounds her, and pleases everyone, much the same way it has you. Nice article, thank you.

I will miss Francis Lam's great articles.  His stories of food and culture are charming and interesting and have provided me great recipes and ideas.  They have also reminded me again and again of the richness this country gains from our immigrant friends.  I wish him the best in his new venture.
This made me cry a little. A wonderful essay. Best of luck on your next project.

Thank you, Francis. My mother made this also, and it was one of my favorites! She called it "tomato stew" and I never took the time to watch her make it. Too busy eating it! Now I can make it and bring back all those memories ...

I live and work in China, and discovered this dish here. It is the ultimate comfort food; it is the first pan to be replenished in the canteen when it's served for lunch; it is the dish I urge my senior high school students to learn to make before they leave for university in the UK or the US. "You won't find this there," I say, "not like your grandmother makes, or your dad."  My own son was born in China, and every Saturday morning, I make him pancakes, like my dad did for me. Living outside your home culture requires resilience in the kitchen as well as the heart.

Thank you, Francis!  As a Korean American who has lived in the US nearly my entire life, I understand what it is to sit on the margins of a culture, never quite immersed. I have loved your column, and I am sure I will love these eggs. Best wishes on your new venture.

Real Chinese home-cooked food. I haven't made this in a while. Thanks for the recipe. I think I'll be making this soon.

I typically would scramble the eggs, the brown ginger and garlic, add fresh chopped tomatoes, salt, sugar, then add the eggs back to the pan to combine.

It will be interesting to see the difference the sesame oil and scallions make.

Another writer might have given us the story of how this dish came to be, since tomatoes came relatively recently (the blink of an eye in Chinese culture) from the Western Hemisphere. But you gave us the story of its heart and soul, as you have for so many dishes (and their people). Thank you for the past two years.

I love this! I came to the US from China with my parents when I was just 6, and this is still one of my favorites dishes. It's so easy to make and it is such a staple in Chinese cuisine that no one really thinks twice about it but that's what makes it traditional.

Definitely a recipe and worth bookmarking for use when my garden is filled with ripe Jersey tomato's. You can never have enough recipes for eggs. Thanks! Only thing I might add are some toasted sesame seeds just because I like them.

My Greek mother (now aged 95) used to cook a similar dish for my brother and me when we were young. I make it for breakfast often. Sautéed tomatoes, beaten eggs, a sprinkling of Greek oregano, salt and pepper and sometimes a few gratings of cheese. Quick, easy and still comforting.

As a Filipino-American, I grew up with this too. My mother, who often prepared breakfast on the weekends. usually made scrambled eggs with tomatoes, tortang talong (roasted eggplant dredged in egg and fried), fried spam/canned meat and garlic rice. Even while visiting the Philippines at various relatives homes, if breakfast was prepared, scrambled eggs with tomatoes was usually on the table while I was there. I never thought of the Chinese connection but it makes sense now.

commentBody: As I read the story, I was shocked that two of her friends killed themselves, and upset about the fact that "Native American teenagers and young adults are 1.5 times as likely to kill themselves as the national average..." (Saul Elbein). My emotions were on a roller coaster! I was also happy because there are people out there that can make others happy. I feel like every teenager can make a good difference. For example, they could always make their own friends have a smile!

It is often questioned if teenagers can make a difference in the world, yet the answer is as clear as ever. Of course teenagers can make a difference, it only takes ambition.  As it was seen in  the article, “Do You Think Teenagers Can Make a Difference in the World?,” a simple teenager, by the name of Charger, was able to create a youth group in order to keep people happy and prevent them from committing suicide. What makes Charger so special, you may be thinking;  nothing, he only had a goal and he set out to achieve it. Who’s to say we, fellow teenegars, can’t do the same? All that is required is one person with an objective and anything is possible. Individuals such as Malala Yousafzai, a girl who fought for girl’s education, and Yash Gupta, a boy who created a company which donates glasses to those in need, were just teenagers;  yet, once they had an idea in their heads, they aimed to make it a reality and they succeeded and changed the world. Alexander the Great once said, “There is nothing impossible to him who will try,” meaning that nothing is impossible if you try your hardest, no matter if you are just a teenager, you can make a difference.

I’ve always thought that changing the world was unrealistic, that it was so farfetched that only one person out of a billion could do. Most of the people you read on the news or media that change the world are much more older and experienced but to see someone so young like Jasilyn Charger do something so courageous and strong really has made me reconsider my thoughts of changing the world. It all started with a simple group Jasilyn formed where “They raised money for basketball tournaments and for a youth trip to the Red Nation Film Festival in California, where the kids were able to see the ocean for the first time in their landlocked lives.” I would have never thought that an action made by a group so small could later make such an impactful move such as helping the Dakota Access Pipeline. After reading the article I realized that Jasilyn had done something I had thought was impossible after all these years. There are many ways that teenagers just like Jasilyn can change the world. Many people think that such small actions like holding a door for someone or giving a seat to the elderly won’t necessarily change the world but they are wrong. I think teenagers can change the world one at a time by doing acts of kindness and while it may seem small it is still powerful and it sends a message. I want to do something similar to Jasilyn or even greater than her actions to leave my mark on the earth one day.

Before I read this article, I thought that one teenager couldn't change the world but I was proved wrong. One teenager could change the world for the better. As I read the story, my feelings were all over the place. I felt sad that the girl had to deal with the death of her two best friends, one after another. The article states, "Jasilyn Charger was 19 when she learned her best friend had killed herself." This quote impacted me immediately; I was shocked. The author wrote, "Then, two days later, while she was still in Eagle Butte-the largest town on the Cheyenne River Reservation with a population of 1,300-another friend killed herself." It made me realize that the hardest impact in life can wake you up and make you acknowledge what is happening around you. I was inspired to help out my community. Charger said, "Yeah, it looks all pretty on Facebook but really, what's going on in real life? You can be busy getting on Snapchat while someone's getting bullied." This made me realize that social media can distract you from reality. Teenagers should get together, and encourage others to help one another.

As I read the story, I felt sympathetic for Jasilyn Charger. I can't even imagine what it would feel like to lose two of your best friends! The article states. "..she flew home for her friend’s funeral..another friend killed herself. Charger was shocked." I then read that she started a youth group that helped teenagers look out for each other. I felt happy knowing that there are people who actually care about this topic. I was actually surprised that her small group became a movement. I had no idea that so many teens felt this way and required guidance. I now know that this is a real problem, and I want to help do something about it. There are things that teens (or a teen) can do. An idea would be to arrange talks. You don't need to spread the word about this subject only to teenagers who are feeling suicidal. Talking to as many people as possible can drastically influence the number of teens who 'attempt' or 'complete.' By talking to large audiences, the message that you are trying to convey will reach more people. It doesn't matter if you are a group or not, you can still make a difference. The article encourages anyone who wants to make a difference to do so. Like I said before, anyone can make a difference. The first step to doing so would be to take action. Put up flyers, start a group, even hold talk seminars. But it is important to take action and spread a positive message!

Women who seek more than a domestic life is seen as heartless, greedy, or power hungry. Girls are exposed to images of women that don’t represent them, and are therefore more prone to eating disorders and body dysmorphia. Some people think that women are not suitable for politics because they think that they will make rash decisions due to their menstrual cycle. Girls are sexualized at a young age. Yet, when they finally feel confident in their bodies, they are called numerous demeaning names. Girls are taught that the only way they can find happiness is in not in themselves, but in a man. I often think about the injustice we face and how if we were men, our lives would be easier. However, I then think about the issues that men face as well and realize that they can’t be ignored. The hyper masculinity that boys have to live up to every single day of their lives since the day they were born upsets me. From the second they breathe their first breath, their favorite color has to be blue and they have to live up to the idea of what a man should be. The moment they step away from the mold of what a “man” is, they are called gay. If they cry, they are told to “man up.” Men who have depression are more likely to resort to violent behavior, drugs, and alcohol. Consequently, the rate of suicide in males is rising, which is not a trend seen in females. (Part 2)

As I was reading this story, I felt shocked, sad, and hopeful. It states, “Jasilyn Charger was 19 when she learned her best friend had killed herself… It hurt all of us because there were people who we thought we knew but really we had no idea what they were going through.” The passage continues by giving statistics that really shocked me. Saul Elbein writes, “Native American teenagers and adults are 1.5 times as likely to kill themselves as the national average.” I felt hopeful, however, when I read how Charger created change by forming a youth group. I was inspired by her efforts to help reduce suicides among young people in her community because every time I hear a story about how the youth are creating change, it gives me hope that we will be the generation that becomes the change we hope to see in the world. I was not surprised by the way her desire snowballed into a movement and made a real difference because she was focusing on an issue that was affecting many Native Americans. Because she set her mind to preventing a problem that instilled a lot of fear in a population, she was bound to create change.
A problem that I would like to do something about is gender inequality. Growing up, I noticed how girls were looked down upon. Whether it be in gym class or in the classroom, we were not seen as equals. Now that my knowledge extends farther than my own classroom, I can see that it is a bigger problem than I thought. (Part 1)

Even after reading the article “Do You Think Teenagers Can Make a Difference in the World?” by Caroline Crosson Gilpin, i still believe teenagers can make a difference in the world. While reading this article, I first felt upset when I was reading about Jasilyn Charger and how her friend had killed herself. As i continued to read this article, the article stated, “By the end of that summer, Jasilyn told me, 30 Cheyenne River kids attempted and eight completed.” At this point, I was wondering if there could be something these teenagers could do to stop these actions. Finally, I read, “Together with White Eyes and their friend, Trenton Casillas-Bakeberg, [Charger] formed a youth group.” This only proves that teenagers can make a difference in the world. Sometimes adults do not understand how teenagers think, but one teenager can understand another. I believe if teens come together, they can change the world for the better. Whether you’re saving lives, or making changes to the community, if teenagers come together, they can make a difference in our world like Jasilyn Charger and her friends.

Do I think teenagers can make a difference in the world? Definitely so many teenagers have already changed the world. Jasilyn Charger is one of the many teens who have made a difference. After she had lost two close friends it really woke her up. She stated “It hurt all of us because these were people who we thought we knew but really we had no idea what they were going through, It really woke us up.” Together with a couple of friends they did many great things for native americans, including being apart of the local campaign against the Keystone XL pipeline. Teenagers from all-around came together with many others to take part in the campaign. When teens see something unfair or wrong they will fight with all their might to make it right. So, in conclusion teens are probably the best people to make a difference in the world.

I know that children of any age can make a difference, as proven on the website of Young Voices for the Planet [http://www.youngvoicesonclimatechange.com].
As an inspirational lesson plan, just watch the videos with your class and see how empowered they are by seeing the differences that other young folks are making.

In relation to what these teenagers are confronting in these places of the nation to kill themselves is very worrying, for the reason that life is the most sacred thing we have all human beings, and that teenagers are the future of our society.

It is very important and necessary that the local authorities pay close attention to this situation. This is a very serious situation that has been happening, and I think this problem has a solution. There are several programs that the authorities can implement so that these teenagers remain occupied and that they do not take the suicide as the only way to solve their problems.
There are programs of rehabilitation, sports, education, etc., which help these young people to stay out of the streets and return to a normal life, to live together with their relatives. It is also very important to implement programs for parents, since the problem of the youth is reflected in the parents, and the problems of the parents in the young.
I think that all the problems in humanity begin in our psychology, from then on, they develop gradually, and if they are not treated properly, then they become a serious problem.

Actually a student from China who went to Germany to give a talk at a conference, was not allowed to return to the US. Her German visa expired and she had to leave Germany as well. She went to China and it took six weeks for her to get permission to return to the US.

A young woman from Trinidad living in the US went to Europe for a vacation. Before being allowed to return to the US she was interviewed by the local US embassy and asked to swear that she was not a prostitute. (She is an academic).

BOTH these events happened under the Obama administration.

Maybe Trump is tougher than Obama, but the world of open borders does not exist and never did and you should not plan for it.

When countries deny a visa, or on rare occasions disallow you to come in despite the fact that you have a visa - it is bad and unfortunate. It should not happen.

But it does not mean that you are living in a fascist world. You are living in the real world which always had such problems.

I never thought I could be ashamed to be an American, but stories like this make me feel just that way. And, like Mr. Kristoff, I feel we all owe the author, and those like him, an apology.

The Johnson Act further identifies this division and is very clear that if violated churches will be taxed.

In the case of Citizens United the Supreme Court enabled the expansion of corporate political contributions to Political Action Committees that don’t coordinate messages with individual candidates. This was expected to favor business in general and Republicans in particular. While Democrats have been successful in obtaining large contributions from many corporate sectors; the election of Donald Trump and keeping a majority in both houses of Congress makes it clear that voters have been receptive to business interests and the promise of better jobs.
The Johnson Amendment applies to any 501(c)(3) organization such as hospitals and universities; and not just to churches. The law threatens the loss of tax exempt status for conducting political campaign activities intended to impact elections to public office. Donors, large and small, would generally prefer to give to a non-profit and take advantage of a tax deduction than to make nondeductible contributions to political campaigns.
There is a genuine concern by Democrats that religious and family values of many 501(c)(3) organizations are more closely aligned with the right. There is also a legitimate concern by non-profits that it may become necessary to declare and promote a political philosophy in order to attract support. The new bill in Congress seeks to permit some political activity measured by dollars – an invitation for more IRS intrusion. Real freedom of speech may achieve the best balance with no government regulation.

The problem, obviously, is not that clergy do not enjoy the same freedom of speech as everyone else does but that they want THEIR speech subsidized by the taxpayers.  They want to the enjoy their tax-exemption as strictly charitable non-partisan welfare organizations while being free to engage in overtly partisan political activities.  In other words, they want to eat their cake and have it.  If they want to engage in political speech, by all means, let them.  But only if they start paying taxes like everyone else - everyone else except Donald Trump and large corporations, that is - and stop demanding "special rights."
I foresee political action groups calling themselves churches to avoid taxes. Just eliminate tax exemptions for all churches, and let them say anything they want.
Fine, just make sure the tax exemption is destroyed.

On the one hand I don't really mind religions having the right to poltical activity. On the other, it would be a terrible thing to see how religious group would become awash in political money when political parties used them to launder their money.
Republicans like to suggest that all charitable needs can be done by religious groups. I don't believe that for a second but, it may be a good idea to remove their tax exempt status and make them provide charity and make that their basis for tax deductions, just like us.

I have to wonder how many clergy really want a repeal of the Johnson Amendment. Right now, clergy can concentrate on their religious message and stay out of politics. If the amendment is repealed, however, they will face pressure to take a political stand. In our highly charged, divisive environment, any stand clergy take is bound to anger at least half of their congregation, leading to a loss of members and/or internal power struggles. For the sake of religion, it is probably best to keep the Johnson Amendment.

I appreciate coverage of this issue, but I think the phrasing is misleading.
To say that the law " that prohibits churches from endorsing or opposing political candidates" makes it sound like it's suppressing free speech.
The truth is, any church can say whatever they want and be political. There is no prohibitions on churches saying what they want. They simply can't also ask for tax exempt status. Churches are not required to be tax exempt, but if the government is going to give them money, in essence, then they shouldn't spend that tax break on favoring one party or another.

The church becomes a power base detracting from it's very purpose as a church . Its concern should stay with matters spiritual and not whether to propound block borders or  holy wars against invisible opponents. Let their ministers from the lowest to the highest  speak out - for themselves as individuals on the good or bad of the society they live in.  Heaven - in whatever form you perceive -  it forbid they have a Minister for political affairs

If a church actually does charitable or community valued work, they should have a financially separate charitable entity for which contributions could be tax deductible. The truth is that non-religious charities also are barred from making political statements supporting candidates. Why should my tax dollars go to support any religious community? Why should I have to support Scientology or any local preacher who opens a storefront church? I hope states and local communities will begin to change this and stop allowing religious communities to escape state income taxes and property taxes.

The separation of church and state was intended to defend the church from the state. The purpose of the First Amendment is to protect religion from government, not the other way around. Hypothetically, taxing a religious organization is an example of dual taxation expect for one important proviso. The congregation supporting the church/temple/mosque is also exempt from taxation on the proceeds they contribute to the institution. The restriction placed upon the institution is to curtail any overt political advocacy within the Constitutional boundaries of the First Amendment. We all know they lobby anyway but they do so discretely. Hence, we have our current equilibrium.

However, by removing such restrictions on religious institutions specifically, you've just created a huge mess. I'll use an analogy from the secular sector. Non-profits that don't lobby are tax exempt. They are known as 501(c)3. Religious institutions fall under this category. Non-profits that do lobby fall under a different numerical designation. 501(c)x for example. These organizations need to pay taxes. If you grant tax preference to religious institutions alone, what happens to the world of non-profits generally?

As a Christian pastor, I have no desire to preach support for any specific candidate from the pulpit. Like any concerned citizen, I might discuss candidates in personal conversations. This does not mean politically charged issues cannot or should not be addressed from the pulpit. For example:

1) Abortion - historic Christian faith teaches that life begins at conception, and that all human beings are created in the image of God and should be protected. And yes, we are pro-life in the fullest sense. We support our local Pregnancy Care Center offering prenatal care, we serve free community meals with free coats and clothing, we minister to those in hospitals and nursing homes.

2) Marriage - Marriage as defined by the Christian Scriptures are the union of one man and one woman. We respect those who disagree.

3) Religious Liberty - People should be free to believe and worship freely in line with their consciences. This includes the various denominations of the Christian faith, as well as all other religions, and the "nones."

4) Social Justice - all forms of racism, xenophobia, sexism, etc., whether found in personal relationships or enshrined in policies or laws are sinful.

5) Concern for the poor - We are responsible to care for and be generous to those suffering in poverty, the mentally and physically ill, etc.

Whether these issues put us on the left or the right, in line with a specific candidate or not, is not my concern as a Christian minister.
